From 17 January 2022 Galiwin'ku will be in lockdown for 7 days. There are additional lockouts in place.      The lockdown applies to everyone, whether or not they are vaccinated. Essential workers who are fully vaccinated can continue to go to work.    People can only leave home to:    -receive medical treatment, including COVID testing or vaccination  -obtain essential goods and services, like groceries, power tokens and medications â only one household member once per day  -do 1 hour of outdoor exercise per day, with one other person or people from your household â masks are required while exercising  -provide care and support to a family member or person who cannot support themselves, or in case of an emergency    https://web.archive.org/web/20220121170948/https://www.healthdirect.gov.au/covid19-restriction-checker/hotspots-and-case-locations/nt  https://web.archive.org/web/20220114131655/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/stay-safe/slow-spread/information-about-face-masks

Only essential workers who are fully vaccinated can continue to go to work. There are lockdowns in place for Ampilatwatja, Milikapiti, Galiwinâku, Gunyangara, Wurrumiyanga and all land known as the Utopia Homelands. Currently the longest lockdown is for Elcho Island including Galiwinâku and the Wessel Islands including Martjanba, until 31 January 2022. However lockdowns and lockouts continue to be extended or put in place.     During a lockdown, residents must stay at home and are only permitted to leave for the following four reasons:    - Medical treatment, including COVID testing and vaccination  - For essential goods and services, like groceries, medications or power tokens. Only one household member should visit the store, once per day  - For one hour of outdoor exercise a day within 5 km from your home with one other person or people from your house  - To provide care and support to a family member or person who cannot support themselves, or in the case of an emergency including escaping harm from domestic/family violence .  - Essential workers who are fully vaccinated can continue to go to work.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220129102123/https://www.healthdirect.gov.au/covid19-restriction-checker/hotspots-and-case-locations/nt  https://web.archive.org/web/20220129102206/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/stay-safe/slow-spread/current-restrictions

Lockdowns have ended but there are lock-ins in place for Ampilatwatja, Palumpa, Milingimbi, Milikapiti, Elcho and Wessel Islands. The lock-in applies until 6 February 2022.    You canât leave a lock-in area unless you are an authorised officer or essential worker. You donât need to stay at home during the lock-in â unless you are a COVID-19 positive case or a close contact of a positive case â but you canât leave the community without an exemption.    Proof of vaccination is required to enter:  - Bars, pubs and nightclubs licensed to sell and consume liquor on premises  - Clubs licensed to sell and consume liquor on premises  - Casinos and licensed gaming venues  - Restaurants with a liquor licence  - Cinema, theatre, concert, music or dance hall.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220129102123/https://www.healthdirect.gov.au/covid19-restriction-checker/hotspots-and-case-locations/nt  https://web.archive.org/web/20220129102206/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/stay-safe/slow-spread/current-restrictions

Ex. in the NT Community and recreation centres, play centres and public libraries can operate. Proof of vaccination is required to enter:  - pubs and clubs  - casinos  - restaurants  - cinemas and theatres  - ticketed events for more than 500 people in urban centres or more than 100 people in non-urban centres    Events with less than 500 people don't require a checklist or safety plan, however the physical distancing and hygiene principles should still be considered and implemented.    Events with 500 to 1000 people do require completion of a COVID-19 Small Event Checklist. From 13 Jan to 20 Jan there are lockouts in the NT areas of Amoonguna, Yuendumu and Yuelamu.     During a lockout, fully vaccinated residents can live normally within a lockout area. Unvaccinated people aged 16 years and over, including people whoâve received only their first dose of a COVID-19 vaccine, must stay at home during a lockout period and are only permitted to leave for essential reasons.     You canât travel more than 30km from your home when leaving for 1 of the 3 reasons. If you need to go to the hospital and itâs more than 30km from your home, thatâs permitted.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220114131655/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/stay-safe/slow-spread/information-about-face-masks

Lockdowns and lockouts in the NT areas. Although regulations vary, all interstate travel is restricted to some degree. All travelers to the Northern Territory must complete a border entry form. Entry is prohibited from current hotspots or public exposure sites without a prior approved exemption attached to your border entry form. The government of Western Australia (WA) has enacted a controlled interstate border arrangement. All travelers must register online before traveling to Western Australia. The areas where travelers have spent time prior to arriving in Western Australia determine conditions of their entry and any possible quarantine, vaccination, and/or COVID-19 testing requirements. Currently all areas of AUS are considered an extreme risk. You are not permitted to enter without an approval through G2G Pass (external link). Exemptions are restricted to Commonwealth, State and specialist functions only; If permitted entry, you will be directed to undertake 14 days hotel quarantine at a Government approved quarantine facility at your own expense.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220107081429/https://au.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220129102123/https://www.healthdirect.gov.au/covid19-restriction-checker/hotspots-and-case-locations/nt  https://web.archive.org/web/20220129102206/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/stay-safe/slow-spread/current-restrictions

No new policy. Continuing from 15 December AUS reopens the borders to fully vaccinated international students and Temporary Graduate (subclass 485) visa holders. Continuing policy restricts other travelers to Australia to fully vaccinated Australians and permanent residents.   https://web.archive.org/web/20220114141037/https://www.health.gov.au/health-alerts/covid-19/international-travel/inbound  https://web.archive.org/web/20220106102244/https://au.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No new policy. Continuing from 15 December AUS reopens the borders to fully vaccinated international students and Temporary Graduate (subclass 485) visa holders. Continuing policy restricts other travelers to Australia to fully vaccinated Australians and permanent residents.     All inbound passengers must also provide proof of vaccination status before arrival through the Australia Travel Declaration, unless they are a child under the age of 12 years and 3 months. It is important to note that previous infection with COVID-19 is not considered a medical contraindication for COVID-19 vaccination.    Passengers providing a medical certificate to provide this proof must ensure that the medical certificate is in English and includes the following information:    -their name (this must match their travel identification documents)  -date of medical consultation and details of their medical practitioner  -details that clearly outline that they have a medical condition that means they cannot receive a COVID-19 vaccination (vaccination is contraindicated).    https://web.archive.org/web/20220116005735/https://www.health.gov.au/health-alerts/covid-19/international-travel/inbound  https://web.archive.org/web/20220106102244/https://au.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No new policies. National policy outlines recommended guidelines to protect the elderly along a three tiered system. The visitation restrictions and guidelines for residential aged care facilities follow social distancing, vaccination and COVID screening norms.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210415104420/https://www.health.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/2020/11/coronavirus-covid-19-national-aged-care-guidance-escalation-tiers-and-aged-care-provider-responses.pdf    https://web.archive.org/web/20211021011733/https://www.health.gov.au/node/18602/coronavirus-covid-19-advice-for-people-in-residential-aged-care-facilities-and-visitors

No new policies. National policy outlines recommended guidelines to protect the elderly along a three tiered system. The visitation restrictions and guidelines for residential aged care facilities follow social distancing, vaccination and COVID screening norms. It is up to providers to manage and mitigate COVID-19 risks to aged care residents, including the risks that isolation poses to their physical, social and emotional wellbeing. Face-to-face get togethers between residents, family members and friends should be facilitated where they can be undertaken safely and are permitted under public health orders. Residents of an aged care facility have the right to choose to have vaccinations or not.      https://web.archive.org/web/20220129111557/https://www.health.gov.au/node/18602/coronavirus-covid-19-advice-for-people-in-residential-aged-care-facilities-and-visitors  https://web.archive.org/web/20220129111557/https://www.agedcarequality.gov.au/sites/default/files/media/letter-commissioner-residential-approved-providers-being-prepared-for-covid-19-outbreak-22-december-2021.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210415104420/https://www.health.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/2020/11/coronavirus-covid-19-national-aged-care-guidance-escalation-tiers-and-aged-care-provider-responses.pdf

No new policy. Continued from 13 September 2021, everyone in Australia aged 12 years and over is eligible for a free COVID-19 vaccination. Phase 2 of reintroducing in-person learning for Bruneian students has commenced on January 17, 2022.    Originally,  "The first phase will begin on January 3, 2022.     The minister explained that in-person teaching and learning for secondary students in Year 10 and Year 11 will be conducted five times a week, including special needs students from Priority Level 1 and 2. Whereas those in Priority Level 3 will only have to attend their physical classes once a week.     For Year 12 and 13 students, as well as Priority Level 1 and 2, and special need students will also undergo face-to-face teaching and learning five times a week, while once a week in-person classes for Priority Level 3 students.     âMeanwhile, teaching and learning for the remaining students will be made via online or Home Learning Pack (HLP). The first phase is planned to be carried out for at least two weeks whereby the transition towards the second phase depending if there is no increase in the spread of serious cases of infections among the students, teachers and staff as well as on the advice of the COVID-19 Steering Committeeâ, the minister explained.     The minister shared that the second phase is expected to begin on January 17, 2022. However, its implementation will depend on the current Covid-19 situation as well.     In the second phase, said the minister, in-person lessons will be carried out five times a week for students who have completed two doses of COVID-19 vaccines and the increased school capacity from 40 to 100 per cent. This is to be implemented for secondary school students from Year 7 to 11, including special need students in Priority Level 1 and 2. Those in Priority Level 3 will have to attend their physical classes thrice a week, and Year 12 and 13 students, including special needs in Priority Level 1 and 2. Classes for special needs students in Priority Level 3 will be carried out thrice a week.     Lessons for students aged 5 to 11 who have yet to receive their vaccination will continue via online and HLP.     âStudents who continue to have difficulties with online learning will be continued to be supported by the school through the provision of HLPâ, the minister stated. "    Additionally, from the frst Scoop report,   "Only fully vaccinated teachers and students can return to primary and secondary schools, sixth form centres and higher education institutions.    Some 98 percent of teachers are fully jabbed while 80 percent of students aged 12-17 have received two vaccine doses, according to education ministry figures.    All double-vaxxed students, teachers and non-teaching staff are still required to undergo antigen rapid tests once a week in the first stage of school reopening."    â    "Toddlers aged 3 to 4 can head back to kindergartens from January 17, the education minister said Wednesday.    Joining the COVID-19 news conference, Dato Hj Hamzah Hj Sulaiman said in-person lessons will be allowed for preschoolers five times a week, but attendance at kindergartens is capped at 30 percent.    To ensure the safety of preschoolers who are not authorised to receive the vaccine against COVID, only kindergartens that meet health requirements can reopen.    Kindergarten pupils will also be required to wear face masks and undergo antigen rapid tests once a week, with only those producing negative results permitted to attend in-person classes.    The minister said parents and guardians of the children must be fully jabbed and show proof of vaccination.    Double-vaccinated Year 7-9 pupils will also return to classrooms next week after a five-month hiatus due to the COVID-19 pandemic, joining Year 10-13 students who were the first group to resume face-to-face classes earlier this month."    "Brunei is still awaiting the arrival of Pfizer vaccines to inoculate children aged 5-11, who are expected to be the last group to return to schools."    See the Scoop's report, entitled "International travel to resume in January, schools to reopen in stages as Brunei enters âearly endemic phase", archived at https://archive.vn/uA4rP#selection-1681.0-1681.129  See the Scoop's report, entitled "Child care centres set to reopen from January 17", archived at https://archive.vn/WZHR9  See the Brunei Post's report, entitled "School reopening, in-person learning to start in stages", archived at https://archive.vn/frKFF

No change.    Business premises can operate to 75 percent or 300-people capacity, whichever is smaller, from 15 December.    "From Wednesday, all people, regardless of vaccination status, will be allowed to enter public premises or attend public events.  However, unvaccinated individuals are required to undergo ART testing at accredited ART Centres. Each test result is valid for two days.  Children under 18 who are unvaccinated or partially vaccinated will be allowed to enter premises without the need for ART testing, provided that they are accompanied by a fully vaccinated adult.  Business and public premises will be allowed to hold 75 percent of their capacity, but not more than 300 people. The rule applies to:    Restaurants, cafÃ©s, food courts, markets and food stalls, cinemas, arcades, indoor playgrounds, beauty establishments, and music schools.  All indoor and outdoor sports, fitness and recreational facilities. (Only training is allowed, no sports competitions.)  Museums, galleries, libraries and senior citizens centres. (Opening hours are restricted to 8am-2pm.)  Government offices and service counters. "    Additionally, the civil service will return to normal in-person working and standard working hours.  "In the early endemic phase, civil servants will fully return to the office and normal working hours will be reinstated from 7.45am to 12.15pm and from 1.30pm to 4.30pm."    The Scoop's report, archived at https://archive.vn/uA4rP#selection-1561.0-1627.41

No change.    "Public venues can increase capacity to 75%  As Brunei moves into the early endemic phase, the government also announced further easing of restrictions that will come into effect on December 15, 2021 and last until January 14, 2022.  During this period, wearing of face masks and use of the Bruhealth contact tracing app will still be mandatory, and the 10pm to 4am curfew will still be in place.  From Wednesday, all people, regardless of vaccination status, will be allowed to enter public premises or attend public events.  However, unvaccinated individuals are required to undergo ART testing at accredited ART Centres. Each test result is valid for two days.  Children under 18 who are unvaccinated or partially vaccinated will be allowed to enter premises without the need for ART testing, provided that they are accompanied by a fully vaccinated adult.  Business and public premises will be allowed to hold 75 percent of their capacity, but not more than 300 people. The rule applies to:    Restaurants, cafÃ©s, food courts, markets and food stalls, cinemas, arcades, indoor playgrounds, beauty establishments, and music schools.  All indoor and outdoor sports, fitness and recreational facilities. (Only training is allowed, no sports competitions.)  Museums, galleries, libraries and senior citizens centres. (Opening hours are restricted to 8am-2pm.)  Government offices and service counters.    Members of the public are permitted to host large gatherings such as weddings, but attendance is limited to 75 percent of the venue capacity or not more than 300 people â whichever is the smaller number. Buffet services are still not allowed, except for dome serving, and distribution of packaged meals is encouraged instead."    The Scoop's report, archived at https://archive.vn/uA4rP

"Public venues can increase capacity to 75%  As Brunei moves into the early endemic phase, the government also announced further easing of restrictions that will come into effect on December 15, 2021 and last until January 14, 2022.   During this period, wearing of face masks and use of the Bruhealth contact tracing app will still be mandatory, and the 10pm to 4am curfew will still be in place.   From Wednesday, all people, regardless of vaccination status, will be allowed to enter public premises or attend public events.  However, unvaccinated individuals are required to undergo ART testing at accredited ART Centres. Each test result is valid for two days.  Children under 18 who are unvaccinated or partially vaccinated will be allowed to enter premises without the need for ART testing, provided that they are accompanied by a fully vaccinated adult.  Business and public premises will be allowed to hold 75 percent of their capacity, but not more than 300 people. The rule applies to:     Restaurants, cafÃ©s, food courts, markets and food stalls, cinemas, arcades, indoor playgrounds, beauty establishments, and music schools.  All indoor and outdoor sports, fitness and recreational facilities. (Only training is allowed, no sports competitions.)  Museums, galleries, libraries and senior citizens centres. (Opening hours are restricted to 8am-2pm.)  Government offices and service counters.     Members of the public are permitted to host large gatherings such as weddings, but attendance is limited to 75 percent of the venue capacity or not more than 300 people  â whichever is the smaller number. Buffet services are still not allowed, except for dome serving, and distribution of packaged meals is encouraged instead."    The Scoop's report, archived at https://archive.vn/uA4rP

No change.    With the transition to the early endemic phase, the Ministry of Transport and Infocommunications have advised that transport vehicles are now limited to 75% capacity, up from 50% previously.    "2. Similarly with Public Transport such as buses, taxis and e-hailing services as well as transport of mining boats, passenger boats and passenger ships where the number of passengers is increased to 75% of the previous total passenger capacity of 50% (excluding drivers) and ensure the existence of social incarceration measures. This means that the vehicle seat capacity and number of passengers for taxis and e-Hailing vehicles such as DART service is according to the vehicle seat capacity for example the vehicle seat capacity is 5 people and the passenger limit is 3 people and so on if the capacity is 7 people and the passenger limit is 4 people."    See the Ministry of Transport and Infocommunications's press release, archived in Malay, at https://archive.vn/vfs6b (see point 2 under SOP Pembukaan Sekolah Memandu dan Pengangkutan Awam)

No change.    Measures have been eased with the commencement of the early endemic phase, with the public allowed to host events up to 75% capacity/300 people, and the civil service returning to work.    However, night-time curfews are still in force and extended to 14th February, with the curfew remaining but shortened to 12 to 4am from 15 January. Up to this date, Brunei's night-time curfews remain from 10pm to 4am.    See the Ministry of Health's press release, archived at https://archive.vn/jK4EU  See the Borneo Bulletin's report on the original Operasi Pulih, published on 02 Oct, archived at https://archive.vn/1gQ2L  See the Borneo Bulletin's report on Operasi Peralihan, published on 10 Nov, archived at https://archive.vn/gwb8w  See the Scoop's report on the early endemic phase, published on 12 Dec, archived at https://archive.vn/uA4rP  See the Scoop's report titled "Movement restrictions shortened from 12am to 4am", published on 10 Jan, archived at https://archive.vn/ttj9L  See the US Embassy in Brunei's COVID-19 Information update, archived at https://archive.vn/FVmPV

No change. The only country-specific exception to the total travel ban is the Reciprocal Green Lane and Vaccinated Travel Lane with Singapore. Other foreigners can only enter Brunei under specific essential travel circumstances (see below). Although a green travel list comprising of other countries such as the United Kingdom and Australia was originally envisioned for the lifting on restriction on non-essential inbound travel on Jan 1, 2022, this has now been scrapped due to concerns over the Omicron variant.    As per the US Embassy in Brunei's website, last updated on 24 Jan, foreigners that do not have a valid reason to enter are banned from entering.    Entry and Exit Requirements:    Are U.S. citizens permitted to enter? No.  Effective September 15, 2020, foreign citizens who meet certain requirements may enter Brunei for essential travel only. All other foreign citizens are barred from entering or transiting Brunei by air, land, or sea. Visit the website of the Prime Ministerâs Office for the latest information.  Citizens, permanent residents, and other residents of Brunei, including foreign citizens who hold a green identity card, require approval from the Prime Ministerâs Office in order to leave the country. This policy does not apply to tourists or other visitors who do not hold Bruneian government-issued identity cards. Residents may apply for permission to leave the country by completing an online application at the website of the Prime Ministerâs Office.  Travelers should be prepared for additional travel restrictions to be put into effect with little to no advance notice. Visit the website of the Brunei Ministry of Health for the latest information.  Is a negative COVID-19 test (PCR and/or serology) required for entry? Yes.  Visit the website of the Prime Ministerâs Office for more information regarding Bruneiâs pre-departure testing requirements.  Are health screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry? Yes.  Brunei International Airport implemented temperature screening requirements for all visitors. Temperature screening is also required at all land and sea-based points of entry into Brunei.  Extensions of social visits, professional visits, or business visits while already in Brunei can be made directly with the Visa, Visit and Diplomatic Section, Department of Immigration and National Registration. Visit the website of the Department of Immigration and National Registration for more information.    Per the Entry Travel Pass requirements, last updated 02 Oct 2020,    The Entry Travel Pass may be issued for the following individuals:  â¢ Essential business travel (including official travel)  â¢ Students  â¢ Individual primarily here for the purpose of medical treatment  â¢ Compassionate and other special circumstances, such as parents, spouse, or other  immediate family members of Brunei Citizens or Residents.  Applications will be reviewed for considerations on a case-to-case basis by authorities.    See the US Embassy in Brunei's website, archived at https://archive.vn/FVmPV  See the Prime Minister Office's guidelines on Entry Travel Pass applications, archived on Dropbox at https://www.dropbox.com/s/j0vr278nkt9dfh4/BRN-20201002-PMO-Guidelines_EntryTravelPassApp.pdf  See the Scoop's report, entitled "Brunei backtracks on plans to lift travel curbs over Omicron concerns", archived at https://archive.vn/8lobr

No changes/deviation; Brunei continues to maintain a systematic, coordinated public campaign re: COVID.    The government continues to maintain an overall website where citizens can access any information related to COVID.   https://archive.vn/PwOIW    There is also an overall site on the Ministry of Health's website pertaining to Covid-19 vaccination (the programme, FAQ, public health messaging).  https://archive.vn/5UFPG    The Ministry of Health continues to update COVID case numbers almost daily (especially since the recent outbreak). See, for example, 19 Jan https://archive.vn/qNfQ5) and 22 Jan (https://archive.vn/Czf24).

The government continues to maintain an overall website where citizens can access any information related to COVID.   https://archive.vn/PwOIW    There is also an overall site on the Ministry of Health's website pertaining to Covid-19 vaccination (the programme, FAQ, public health messaging).  https://archive.vn/5UFPG    The Ministry of Health continues to update COVID case numbers almost daily. See, for example, 09 Feb (https://archive.vn/wip/lIAPM) and 07 Feb (https://archive.vn/yxf2s).    There were missing updates on 06 Feb, 08 Feb, 10â13 Feb.

No change.    As per the US Embassy in Brunei's website, last updated on 24 Jan,    Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Brunei? Yes.  If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours? Yes.  Members of the public who need to undergo a swab test for any reason are advised to go to the Sports Complex, Raja Isteri Pengiran Anak Saleha (RIPAS) Hospital, or other health centers where testing is provided. The testing fee for foreigners is BND $200 [sic, current cost as per Brunei's Ministry of Health is BND $50]. More information is available here. Test results will be delivered through SMS.    See the US Embassy in Brunei's website, archived at https://archive.vn/FVmPV  See the Ministry of Health press release on testing cost (22 May), archived at https://archive.vn/kU9pS

No changes.    On 07 August, Brunei detected its first local Covid-19 cases in over a year, all of which were unlinked to previously-known imported cases. Hence, Brunei has decided to tighten Covid measures, including instituting mandatory mask measures.    Per the press release of 07 Aug by the Ministry of Health,    "Meanwhile, to address the concerns on the spread of Delta variant around the world, including in Brunei Darussalam, the Ministry of Health would also like to inform the public on the changes in the face mask guidelines:    1. Face masks are required be worn at all times, especially indoors or in crowded places either indoor or outdoor.  2. Face mask must cover the wearer's nose and mouth.  3. This directive is applicable to all individuals regardless of their vaccination status."    Per the US Embassy in Brunei's website, last updated on 13 Jan,    "Face masks are mandatory at all times in all indoor and outdoor spaces."    This advice is confirmed in a press conference conducted by the Minister at the Prime Minister's Office, YB Dato Dr Hj Mohd Amin, on 12th December, "During this period, wearing of face masks and use of the Bruhealth contact tracing app will still be mandatory, and the 10pm to 4am curfew will still be in place."    See the Ministry of Health's press release, archived at https://archive.vn/C5fBL  See the US Embassy in Brunei's website, archived at https://archive.vn/HOTWl  See the Scoop's report, archived at https://archive.vn/uA4rP

Vaccines used: Oxford-AstraZeneca (AZD1222/ChAdOx1 nCoV-19); Sinopharm-BIBP (BBIBP-CorV); Moderna (elasomeran); Pfizer-BioNTech (tozinameran)    No changes.    Brunei's Phase 3 of its Vaccination Strategy, for individuals aged 18 years and above, commenced on 05 July. "[Individuals] who wish to get the COVID-19 vaccinations during Phase 3 are required to reserve a slot".    Vaccinations have also been rolled out to adolescents aged 12 to 17 from November 8, utilising the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine.    Booster shots have been available to the general public since 17 December. No change in policy since last iteration.    Additionally, under Brunei's Vaccination Strategy, senior citizens of age 60 and above belong to Phase 1, alongside Bruneians studying abroad and frontliners.    The advice for elderly people to be protected via vaccinations was reiterated on 07 Aug, when Brunei first detected its first local transmission cases in over a year. "Individuals who have not yet received COVID-19 vaccination especially those at high risk such as the elderly and those with chronic diseases are advised to reserve an vaccination slot as soon as possible. Walk-ins at vaccination centres will only be allowed for senior citizens aged 60 and above or individuals with special needs."    See https://web.archive.org/web/20210111022516/http://www.moh.gov.bn/Lists/Latest%20news/NewDispForm.aspx?ID=727  See also, Brunei's Vaccination Strategy, archived on Dropbox, at https://www.dropbox.com/s/yri6djij3ieblma/BRN-202103__-MOH-VaccinationStrategyV2.pdf  See also, IMF's summary on the vaccination groups under "Brunei: Reopening of the Economy", archived at https://web.archive.org/web/20210907090853/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19  See the Ministry of Health's press release dated 07 Aug, archived at https://archive.vn/C5fBL

Zhejiang Jinhua Yongkang Education Bureau decided to resume classes in primary and secondary schools in the city in an orderly manner from January 21.    https://archive.vn/USOyq
In Xi'an, shopping malls, supermarkets, and stores along the street have resumed business since Jan.24th.     https://archive.vn/p0JIF#selection-271.0-271.33

On January 26, Zhejiang Binjiang District shut down chess and card room, bar, KTV, mahjong room, board game room, swimming pool and other indoor closed public places. Yuhang District canceled large-scale activities. Large gatherings such as large-scale literary and artistic performances, exhibition and sales promotion, large-scale forums and temple fairs will be cancelled. Advocate "postponement of weddings, simplification of funerals and no banquets".     http://archive.today/2022.01.26-140819/https://mp.weixin.qq.com/s/3OWWoxbOgbwZjcdz6I46pQ http://archive.today/2022.01.26-140635/https://mp.weixin.qq.com/s/nIaH_3omeINRkyv35zPVzA

Tokyo begin restrictions in response to the omicron variant on January 11 and to continue until the 31st.  Measures require closing restaurants and retail from 9PM and to refrain from serving alcohol after 8PM. Restaurants may continue to serve patrons up to a limit of 4 people per table. For all other businesses remote work from home is encouraged when possible.  Upper limit for event gatherings will also be limited to a maximum of 5,000 or half of the venue's capacity, whichever is the smallest number of attendees. Loud events may only operate at 50% venue capacity, all other events may operate at 100% venue capacity.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220117173206/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1020813.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220117173135/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1020626.html

Priority measures already in effect in Okinawa, Yamaguchi, and Hiroshima will continue until at least January 31st. The government continues to encourage people to avoid dense crowds and situations of high risk for infection, to refrain for unnecessary movement to areas with high infection rates. The government continues to encourage residents to practice precautions moving between prefectures, particularly to and from areas of high infection rates and particularly for those unvaccinated. No change to previous policy.  Japan continues to prohibit entry for non-Visa and leisure travel from all countries. No change to previous policy. New unemployment subsidy application deadlines for January-March 2022 have been set for June 30, 2022 (support document revised as of Dec 23rd).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide financial support in the forms of: employment subsidies to encourage business owners to maintain employees, leave of absence due to COVID-19 infection, living expenses for leave of absence or the unemployed, and special support for low-income child-rearing households for a maximum of 50,000 yen per child. Employment subsidies have a maximum of 15,000 yen per day per person.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220123220658/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html

No change to previous policy. New debt relief subsidy application deadlines for January-March 2022 have been set for June 30, 2022 (support document revised as of Dec 23rd).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide debt relief: loans for small-lot emergency funds and comprehensive unemployment funds are provided at interest-free and payments may be deferred up to one year. Housing security loans are available for those at risk of losing housing: rent payments may be deferred up to 9-months with evidence of employment search. Property tax exemption may be available for applicants facing declining income or unemployment due to the pandemic. For single-parent households, family housing support loan of upto 40,000 yen for 12 months is available interest-free for a one-time redemption if the parent continues to work for a year. Interviews for single-parent households will be conducted to understand their living conditions, motivation for employment, efforts to acquire qualifications, etc. A policy is also in place for the deferment for payments of national taxes.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220123220658/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html

Interviews for single-parent households will be conducted to understand their living conditions, motivation for employment, efforts to acquire qualifications, etc. A policy is also in place for the deferment for payments of national taxes.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220211190020/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220211190012/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdf

Comprehensive public information about COVID-19 continues to be disseminated by the government.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220123220935/https://corona.go.jp/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220123221001/https://corona.go.jp/dashboard/

Comprehensive public information about COVID-19 continues to be disseminated by the government.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220123220935/https://corona.go.jp/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220123221001/https://corona.go.jp/dashboard/

Comprehensive public information about COVID-19 continues to be disseminated by the government.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220211190229/https://corona.go.jp/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220211190253/https://corona.go.jp/dashboard/

No change to previous policy.  Tokyo, Osaka, Okinawa, Fukuoka continues to offer free asymptomatic PCR testing at public and private facilities to all residents of the prefecture.  Tokyo will continue to offer free PCR testing to all individuals until January 31, 2022.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220117175016/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220108/k10013421271000.html (Okinawa evidence)  https://archive.fo/ZpbXV (Osaka & Tokyo)  https://archive.fo/v9SBG (Fukuoka)  https://archive.fo/JyBLE (Tokyo evidence)  https://archive.fo/7Tqmf (Tokyo evidence)  https://web.archive.org/web/20220108013217/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220104/k10013414281000.html (Okinawa evidence)  https://web.archive.org/web/20220108013225/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1020775.html (Tokyo)

While PCR tests continue to be made available to all, at least until the end of January in Tokyo, Nagoya city is beginning to report signs that chemical reagents are limited and testing requires increasing wait for renewed supplies.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220128054458/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220124/k10013447611000.html

Period for free PCR testing have ended on January 31 in Tokyo. Some cities have also been reporting limited reagents and testing capabilities due to demand.  Testing eligibility nationwide continues to be those symptomatic or if contacted by health authority, identified as a close contact.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220128054458/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220124/k10013447611000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220108013225/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/1009757/1020775.html (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20220207233929/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00132.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211213162005/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/kenkou_iryou/dengue_fever_qa_00004.html

To reduce burden on medical facilities due increasing cases and the number of people looking to get tested, Tokyo Metropolitan Government has begun sending antigen test kits to those who apply and identify as close contacts of recently diagnosed cases.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220209115924/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220208/k10013472791000.html

In Okinawa and Hiroshima prefectures, with rising cases and insufficient personnel, standard contact tracing have also been suspended and contact tracing efforts have instead been focused on infections within hospitals, long-term care, and clusters within high risk groups.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220116210406/https://ryukyushimpo.jp/news/entry-1449967.html

In Tokyo, Fukuoka prefecture, and Sapporo, due to significant increase in cases, resources for close contact tracing have also begun prioritizing those in high risk institutions such as medical centres and long term care homes. This is in addition to limited contact tracing in Okinawa and Hiroshima.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220123221611/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220120/k10013439931000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220123221613/https://www.pref.fukuoka.lg.jp/contents/jyuutenka.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220123221813/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/sapporo-news/20220120/7000042505.html

No change to previous policy. Osaka and Nagoya have also been reported to reduce capacity for comprehensive contact tracing in an effort to prioritize cases in high risk institutions. This comes in addition to overwhelmed contact tracing efforts in Tokyo, Fukuoka, Sapporo, Okinawa, and Hiroshima.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220128054301/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220126/k10013450041000.html (Osaka)  https://web.archive.org/web/20220128054458/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220124/k10013447611000.html (Nagoya)  https://web.archive.org/web/20220123221611/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220120/k10013439931000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220123221613/https://www.pref.fukuoka.lg.jp/contents/jyuutenka.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220123221813/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/sapporo-news/20220120/7000042505.html

Reports from other regions including Wakayama city, Matsuyama City, Miyazaki City, and Ehime Prefecture have also seen a significant increase in cases due to omicron, affecting ability to conduct comprehensive contact tracing. Some areas (for example Ehime prefecture) have offloaded regular contact tracing to the general public in an attempt to prioritize contact tracing for high risk facilities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220207234941/https://www.the-miyanichi.co.jp/kennai/_59952.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220207235002/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/matsuyama-news/20220204/8000012074.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220207235017/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/lnews/wakayama/20220204/2040010701.html

No change to previous policy. The wearing of facial masks in Japan is wide spread and continues to be recommended by the government. Masks should also be worn in schools by students and faculty members, and should only be removed when eating or partaking in physical activities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220123213135/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/

No change to previous policy. The wearing of facial masks in Japan is wide spread and continues to be recommended by the government. Masks should also be worn in schools by students and faculty members, and should only be removed when eating or partaking in physical activities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220128044255/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/

No change to previous policy. The wearing of facial masks in Japan is wide spread and continues to be recommended by the government. Masks should also be worn in schools by students and faculty members, and should only be removed when eating or partaking in physical activities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220207205418/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/

On January 13, the government announces the shortening of interval for 3rd doses in the general population to 7 months. Previously for the general public, this period was 8 months. For medical personnel and the elderly population, the interval was previously shortened to 6 months.    Vaccination for children aged 5 to 11 years in Japan is expected to be approved on January 20th.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220117181752/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220113/k10013429491000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220117182101/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220113/k10013429151000.html

On January 21st, 2022, vaccination for children age 5-11 has been approved for the Pfizer vaccine in Japan. The government has begun having discussions with local governments to add children 5-11 to the target of large-scale mass inoculation led by individual prefectures starting from February 1st, 2022.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220123213206/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220121/k10013442001000.html

On January 28 2022, reservations for third dose vaccinations begin open for booking at mass vaccination sites operated by the Self-Defense Forces from the federal government. Booster dose vaccinations are set to begin on January 31st 2022.  The target of large-scale vaccination by the Self-Defense Forces is those who are 18 years of age or older and have a third vaccination ticket, beginning with the elderly population. Those who have not been vaccinated for more than 6 months since the second vaccination will not be vaccinated.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220128201721/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220126/k10013451691000.html

On January 31 2022, third dose vaccination begin being distributed at Tokyo's mass vaccination site. Those who are eligible to book must have received a third-dose vaccination ticket, that is being mailed out by the government beginning with 80+ and step-wise for each age group. Third dose tickets will only be sent to those 18 years old and up, and more than 6-months must have passed since an individual's second dose.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220207235727/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220131/k10013457771000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220207235340/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220130/k10013457321000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220207235402/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220131/k10013458301000.html

On February 7, vaccination for third doses begin being administered at the Osaka mass vaccination site.  In Yokohama City, also Feb 7, third dose vaccination for the elderly population continues to be administered. Yokohama City has the highest number of elderly population (930,000) residing in the country.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220207235928/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220207/k10013470791000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220207235927/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220207/k10013471291000.html

On Feb 10 2022, 20% of children vaccination tickets for children age 5 to 11 in the Koto Ward of Tokyo begin being sent out (~32,000 tickets). Children vaccination are set to begin on March 5 2022.  Mass vaccination for third doses in the elderly population continue to be administered. On Feb 10, the Tokyo mass vaccination site has expanded operations to inoculate 5,040 people per day and Osaka will expand to 2,500 people a day in the following week.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220211192435/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220210/k10013477321000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220211192107/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220210/k10013476591000.html

Third dose vaccination begins in Tokyo's mass vaccination site on January 31 2022. In Osaka, third doses will be administered at the Osaka mass vaccination site beginning February 7. In Yokohama City, the municipal with the largest elderly population residing in the country, third dose vaccinations have already been underway and continues to be administered.    Schedule for third doses are as follows:  Feburary: 1.83 million medical workers and 11.6 million elderly people, 730,000 under 64 years old will be eligible.  March: 890,000 medical workers, 16.24 million elderly people, 64 years old or younger In addition to 4.35 million people, 1.68 million people who are "work-related inoculations" conducted at companies and universities are also eligible.  April: 3.13 million elderly people, 11.94 million people under 64 years old, 5 million occupational inoculations will be eligible.  May: 580,000 elderly people, 14.62 million people under 64 years old, 1.55 million occupational inoculations will be eligible.  June: 350,000 elderly people, 12.73 million under 64 years old, and 2.48 million occupational inoculations will be eligible and continue until September 2022.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211203031729/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211201/k10013369451000.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220207235727/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220131/k10013457771000.html (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20220207235340/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220130/k10013457321000.html (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20220207235402/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220131/k10013458301000.html (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20220207235928/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220207/k10013470791000.html (Osaka)  https://web.archive.org/web/20220207235927/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220207/k10013471291000.html (Yokohama)
NA

Third dose mass vaccination begins in Tokyo, starting with the elderly population. Yokohama City, who has already been administered third doses, continue to inoculate their population. Osaka will begin mass vaccination for third doses (beginning with the elderly) on February 7.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220207235727/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220131/k10013457771000.html (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20220207235340/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220130/k10013457321000.html (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20220207235402/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220131/k10013458301000.html (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20220207235928/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220207/k10013470791000.html (Osaka)  https://web.archive.org/web/20220207235927/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20220207/k10013471291000.html (Yokohama)
NA
All vaccinations continue to be fully covered by the government.    https://archive.fo/Cqn6k

From FB Page of Radio Kiribati (not currently possible to archive link on archive.fo).  Unarchived link at bottom of summary.    *Schools are not referred to in this post.  It does refer to "All arms of government {government agencies) including private businesses will maintain their operations as usual ", suggesting that schools will remain open.    On Friday last week (14th January 2022), 54 passengers arrived on flight from Fiji and had 3 negative test results for Covid-19 prior to departure.  Of these, 36 were subsequently tested (presumably on arrival in Kiribati) with a postive Covid-19 result.  All passengers were according to the report "fully vaccinated", healthy and were in quarantine at Otintaai Hotel.    In addition, one of the 39 frontline staff tested positively for Covid-19.  This person, two colleagues and their families have been "taken into quarantine".    Kiribati is now on Alert Level 2 from 18th January-1st February.  A range of measures are set out:  a) Curfew 10pm-6am  b) Health measures: social distancing, hand washing, wearing masks (apart from at home)  c) Kava and liquor bars closed  d) Gatherings limited to up to 10 people  e) Public transport including ferries will continue to operate    https://www.facebook.com/rknews21/posts/302606985171380?__cft__[0]=AZV3PBsr7Udl4Qwwg7U0GQosJ3lNDt0lXNNlIESVQRyTLVPC8wQFfPAIAIszYZ_VVlhOSvys-85l8y4EOUBeUZGdmWZi9HiMwXDtY90QHR4Kc56pXMl3bMx4QuDDtUq7-oJAihY80KxgyJxyzaeupIScN4f1ZWLfeFgP-FXkbyeWsg&__tn__=%2CO%2CP-R

Announcement from Office of Te Beretitenti (President).  Not possible to archive link on archive.fo, so full link is given after summary.  The article is dated 24th January 2022, but refers to policy changes from 22nd January 2022 that affect South Tarawa, Betio and Buota.    Due to community transmission of Covid-19, from 22nd January 2022 at 3pm, South Tarawa and Betio were moved to Alert Level 3.  Measures include:  a) 24 hour curfew  b) "All essential service providers (food wholesale and retail) from the private sector will remain open to the public from 6am to 2pm."  c) " All Government Offices and SOEs will be closed and work remotely from home, except for essential and emergency services "  d) "People MUST stay at home â may only leave their homes for essential work or to access emergency services."  e) "Access to shops for food shopping and other essential services will be zoned to limit the movement of people within their neighbourhoods or villages from 6am to 2pm."  f) "Public transportation services will cease during the lockdown."  g) "All kava bars, liquor bars, and night clubs will be closed."  h) "All kinds of social gatherings are banned."  i) "Only those stranded in the outer islands are allowed to return to Tarawa provided they meet health travel requirements."  j) "No travels between the outer islands are allowed."    https://www.president.gov.ki/news/91-ana-kaongora-ni-kamataata-h-e-beretitenti-taneti-maamau-iaon-te-covid-19-n-rekereke-ma-alert-level-3.html

From FB page of Office of Te Beretitenti (president)    "The Government has decided to extend the lockdown period on South Tarawa, Betio and Buota for 7 more days effective from 6am Friday 28 January 2022 to 6am Friday 4 February 2022. Furthermore, Te Beretitenti has also signed the extension of the Proclamation of a State Disaster to prepare for and manage the impact of novel corona virus 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic for another 30 days effective from Saturday 29 January 2022 to 28 February 2022, following the first proclamation made on 22 January 2022. "    "Noting that South Tarawa, Betio and Buota are still on alert level three, the following measures are still in effect:  Delivery of cargoes, fuels and medical supplies by vessel or air service will continue to the outer islands with no passengers allowed. Only those stranded in the outer islands are allowed to return to Tarawa provided they meet health travel requirements. No travels between the outer islands are allowed.  1. Lock-down with 24 hours curfew.   2. All Government Offices and SOEs will be closed and work remotely from home, except for essential and emergency services.  â¢ Hospital services  â¢ Police services   â¢ Banking services  â¢ Kiribati Port Authority  â¢ Kiribati Oil Company and gas stations   â¢ Wholesalers and retailers selling food and essential items including Kiribati Copra Development Limited  â¢ Ministry of Finance and Economic Development   â¢ Ministry of Tourism, Commerce, Industry and Cooperatives   â¢ Telecommunication service providers   â¢ Public Broadcasting Authority   â¢ Public Utilities Board  â¢ Kiribati Meteorological Service  â¢ Ministry of Women, Youth, Sport and Social Affairs   â¢ Ministry of Information, Communication and Transport   â¢ Shipping and Aviation service providers  â¢ Kiribati Red Cross Society   â¢ Kiribati Family Health Association   â¢ Kiribati Fish Limited (KFL)   â¢ Central Pacific Producers Limited (CPPL)   3. And other essential services that the Government deems necessary during the lockdown.  These additional services require prior approval of Office of Te Beretitenti.    4. All essential service providers (food wholesale and retail) from the private sector will remain open to the public from 6am to 2pm.   5. People MUST stay at home â may only leave their homes for essential work or to access emergency services.   6. Access to shops for food shopping and other essential services will be zoned to limit the movement of people within their neighbourhoods or villages from 6am to 2pm. Movement to other villages requires prior approval of the Office of Te Beretitenti.   7. Fishing during shopping hours from 6am to 2pm is hereby allowed and that fishing boats or net fishing near shore is restricted to a group of 4 or a maximum of 4 crew for fishing boats. All fishing boats are not allowed to visit other villages or islands apart from their point of origin.  8. Public transportation services will cease during the lockdown.   9. All kava bars, liquor bars, and night clubs will be closed.  10. All kinds of social gatherings are banned.  11. Access to hospital services will be conducted according to the Ministry of Health and Medical Service guidelines as earlier announced.    12.  Delivery of cargoes, fuels and medical supplies by vessel or air service will continue to the outer islands with no passengers allowed. Only those stranded in the outer islands are allowed to return to Tarawa provided they meet health travel requirements.   13.  No travels between the outer islands are allowed.  Update for Buota  The 10 days lockdown of Buota is now uplifted, however, peopleâs movement in and out of Buota will be restricted like the rest of South Tarawa.  This means that those wishing to enter or leave Buota for work or for other essential purposes will need to obtain a pass from the Office of Te Beretitenti (OB), similar with the movement of people between containment zones such as Betio to Bairiki.   In addition to the above, an EFTPOS machine will be made available in Buota for those needing to withdraw cash or for purchasing essential needs.   The public is advised to continue to strictly follow the Ministry of Health and Medical Services Standard Operational Procedures and comply with the curfew order to safeguard themselves and their families from this pandemic.  All requests for this weekend (Saturday 29th and Sunday 30th of January) passes are to reach the Office of the Beretitenti before 4pm on Friday 28th January 2022.  For Companies, Businesses, Ministries and Diplomatic Missions whose requests have been approved this week, these will be extended for the curfew period.    Government will continue to provide regular updates to the public for their information and safety."    http://archive.today/a205w

On Friday last week (14th January 2022), 54 passengers arrived on flight from Fiji and had 3 negative test results for Covid-19 prior to departure.  Of these, 36 were subsequently tested (presumably on arrival in Kiribati) with a postive Covid-19 result.  All passengers were according to the report "fully vaccinated", healthy and were in quarantine at Otintaai Hotel.    In addition, one of the 39 frontline staff tested positively for Covid-19.  This person, two colleagues and their families have been "taken into quarantine".    Kiribati is now on Alert Level 2 from 18th January-1st February.  A range of measures are set out:  a) Curfew 10pm-6am  b) Health measures: social distancing, hand washing, wearing masks (apart from at home)  c) Kava and liquor bars closed  d) Gatherings limited to up to 10 people  e) Public transport including ferries will continue to operate    http://archive.today/8Iq4t

From FB page of Office of Te Beretitenti (president)    "The Government has decided to extend the lockdown period on South Tarawa, Betio and Buota for 7 more days effective from 6am Friday 28 January 2022 to 6am Friday 4 February 2022. Furthermore, Te Beretitenti has also signed the extension of the Proclamation of a State Disaster to prepare for and manage the impact of novel corona virus 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic for another 30 days effective from Saturday 29 January 2022 to 28 February 2022, following the first proclamation made on 22 January 2022. "    "Noting that South Tarawa, Betio and Buota are still on alert level three, the following measures are still in effect:  Delivery of cargoes, fuels and medical supplies by vessel or air service will continue to the outer islands with no passengers allowed. Only those stranded in the outer islands are allowed to return to Tarawa provided they meet health travel requirements. No travels between the outer islands are allowed.  1. Lock-down with 24 hours curfew.   2. All Government Offices and SOEs will be closed and work remotely from home, except for essential and emergency services.  â¢ Hospital services  â¢ Police services   â¢ Banking services  â¢ Kiribati Port Authority  â¢ Kiribati Oil Company and gas stations   â¢ Wholesalers and retailers selling food and essential items including Kiribati Copra Development Limited  â¢ Ministry of Finance and Economic Development   â¢ Ministry of Tourism, Commerce, Industry and Cooperatives   â¢ Telecommunication service providers   â¢ Public Broadcasting Authority   â¢ Public Utilities Board  â¢ Kiribati Meteorological Service  â¢ Ministry of Women, Youth, Sport and Social Affairs   â¢ Ministry of Information, Communication and Transport   â¢ Shipping and Aviation service providers  â¢ Kiribati Red Cross Society   â¢ Kiribati Family Health Association   â¢ Kiribati Fish Limited (KFL)   â¢ Central Pacific Producers Limited (CPPL)   3. And other essential services that the Government deems necessary during the lockdown.  These additional services require prior approval of Office of Te Beretitenti.    4. All essential service providers (food wholesale and retail) from the private sector will remain open to the public from 6am to 2pm.   5. People MUST stay at home â may only leave their homes for essential work or to access emergency services.   6. Access to shops for food shopping and other essential services will be zoned to limit the movement of people within their neighbourhoods or villages from 6am to 2pm. Movement to other villages requires prior approval of the Office of Te Beretitenti.   7. Fishing during shopping hours from 6am to 2pm is hereby allowed and that fishing boats or net fishing near shore is restricted to a group of 4 or a maximum of 4 crew for fishing boats. All fishing boats are not allowed to visit other villages or islands apart from their point of origin.  8. Public transportation services will cease during the lockdown.   9. All kava bars, liquor bars, and night clubs will be closed.  10. All kinds of social gatherings are banned.  11. Access to hospital services will be conducted according to the Ministry of Health and Medical Service guidelines as earlier announced.    12.  Delivery of cargoes, fuels and medical supplies by vessel or air service will continue to the outer islands with no passengers allowed. Only those stranded in the outer islands are allowed to return to Tarawa provided they meet health travel requirements.   13.  No travels between the outer islands are allowed.  Update for Buota  The 10 days lockdown of Buota is now uplifted, however, peopleâs movement in and out of Buota will be restricted like the rest of South Tarawa.  This means that those wishing to enter or leave Buota for work or for other essential purposes will need to obtain a pass from the Office of Te Beretitenti (OB), similar with the movement of people between containment zones such as Betio to Bairiki.   In addition to the above, an EFTPOS machine will be made available in Buota for those needing to withdraw cash or for purchasing essential needs.   The public is advised to continue to strictly follow the Ministry of Health and Medical Services Standard Operational Procedures and comply with the curfew order to safeguard themselves and their families from this pandemic.  All requests for this weekend (Saturday 29th and Sunday 30th of January) passes are to reach the Office of the Beretitenti before 4pm on Friday 28th January 2022.  For Companies, Businesses, Ministries and Diplomatic Missions whose requests have been approved this week, these will be extended for the curfew period.    Government will continue to provide regular updates to the public for their information and safety."    http://archive.today/a205w

Announcement from Office of Te Beretitenti (President).  Not possible to archive link on archive.fo, so full link is given after summary.  The article is dated 24th January 2022, but refers to policy changes from 22nd January 2022 that affect South Tarawa, Betio and Buota.    Due to community transmission of Covid-19, from 22nd January 2022 at 3pm, South Tarawa and Betio were moved to Alert Level 3.  Measures include:  a) 24 hour curfew  b) "All essential service providers (food wholesale and retail) from the private sector will remain open to the public from 6am to 2pm."  c) " All Government Offices and SOEs will be closed and work remotely from home, except for essential and emergency services "  d) "People MUST stay at home â may only leave their homes for essential work or to access emergency services."  e) "Access to shops for food shopping and other essential services will be zoned to limit the movement of people within their neighbourhoods or villages from 6am to 2pm."  f) "Public transportation services will cease during the lockdown."  g) "All kava bars, liquor bars, and night clubs will be closed."  h) "All kinds of social gatherings are banned."  i) "Only those stranded in the outer islands are allowed to return to Tarawa provided they meet health travel requirements."  j) "No travels between the outer islands are allowed."    https://www.president.gov.ki/news/91-ana-kaongora-ni-kamataata-h-e-beretitenti-taneti-maamau-iaon-te-covid-19-n-rekereke-ma-alert-level-3.html

Announcement official Presidential Web Portal dated 12th January 2022    Confirms that Kiribati borders are now open and lists a range of measures - international arrivals only via South Tarawa, requires quarantine, does not exclude countries with active transmission of Covid-19 but does require more stringent conditions for arrivals from these countries.    "All incoming passengers will be required to provide proof of vaccination, COVID-19 test results, and will be quarantined upon arrival. Extra quarantine days for travellers from high-risk countries will be imposed in line with updated travel SOPs to safeguard Kiribati from COVID-19."    "The Taskforce confirmed that travellers from countries with active community transmissions of COVID-19 like Fiji and Australia, are required to be quarantined ten days before their departure and to be tested 48 hours before their flights. Upon arrival, these passengers will be tested again and quarantined for 14 days. Passengers who tested positive for COVID-19 will not be allowed to board inbound flights."    http://archive.today/2022.01.17-170807/https://www.president.gov.ki/news/88-kiribati-border-is-now-open-under-the-new-normal-conditions.html

From FB Page of Radio Kiribati    *There is no reference to closure of borders in this announcement.      There is no reference to this being targeted to South Tarawa and Betio, so is assumed to be general    On Friday last week (14th January 2022), 54 passengers arrived on flight from Fiji and had 3 negative test results for Covid-19 prior to departure.  Of these, 36 were subsequently tested (presumably on arrival in Kiribati) with a postive Covid-19 result.  All passengers were according to the report "fully vaccinated", healthy and were in quarantine at Otintaai Hotel.    In addition, one of the 39 frontline staff tested positively for Covid-19.  This person, two colleagues and their families have been "taken into quarantine".    Kiribati is now on Alert Level 2 from 18th January-1st February.  A range of measures are set out:  a) Curfew 10pm-6am  b) Health measures: social distancing, hand washing, wearing masks (apart from at home)  c) Kava and liquor bars closed  d) Gatherings limited to up to 10 people  e) Public transport including ferries will continue to operate    http://archive.today/8Iq4t

Announcement from Office of Te Beretitenti (President).  Not possible to archive link on archive.fo, so full link is given after summary.  The article is dated 24th January 2022, but refers to policy changes from 22nd January 2022 that affect South Tarawa, Betio and Buota.    *The measures outlined below do not refer to closing borders    Due to community transmission of Covid-19, from 22nd January 2022 at 3pm, South Tarawa and Betio were moved to Alert Level 3.  Measures include:  a) 24 hour curfew  b) "All essential service providers (food wholesale and retail) from the private sector will remain open to the public from 6am to 2pm."  c) " All Government Offices and SOEs will be closed and work remotely from home, except for essential and emergency services "  d) "People MUST stay at home â may only leave their homes for essential work or to access emergency services."  e) "Access to shops for food shopping and other essential services will be zoned to limit the movement of people within their neighbourhoods or villages from 6am to 2pm."  f) "Public transportation services will cease during the lockdown."  g) "All kava bars, liquor bars, and night clubs will be closed."  h) "All kinds of social gatherings are banned."  i) "Only those stranded in the outer islands are allowed to return to Tarawa provided they meet health travel requirements."  j) "No travels between the outer islands are allowed."    https://www.president.gov.ki/news/91-ana-kaongora-ni-kamataata-h-e-beretitenti-taneti-maamau-iaon-te-covid-19-n-rekereke-ma-alert-level-3.html

There have been no references to re-instituting the border closure in recent responses to Covid-19 cases and the Office of the President website continues to refer to the borders being open from 10th January 2022.  (The border had been closed from March 2020-10th January 2022)

No specific reference is made in the guidelines to the international border which was opened on 10th January 2022.  Given that the guidelines indicate that no passengers are allowed on vessels or air services to the outer islands, it is likely that the international border is also effectively closed to international passengers.  Nevertheless the Office of Te Beretitenti website continues to refer to the planned border opening of 10th January and has not been changed since the emergency orders have been introduced.    "Delivery of cargoes, fuels and medical supplies by vessel or air service will continue to the outer islands with no passengers allowed. Only those stranded in the outer islands are allowed to return to Tarawa provided they meet health travel requirements. No travels between the outer islands are allowed."    http://archive.today/a205w

13/02/22    YANGON, Nov. 1 (Xinhua): Myanmar reopened all basic education schools on Monday, including private schools and Buddhist monastic schools, with a decrease in daily Covid-19 infections in the country.    According to an announcement of Central Committee on Prevention, Control and Treatment for Covid-19, schools in 46 townships of nine regions and states will be excluded from reopening based on the analysis on the test positivity rates per 100,000 people in the past 14 days.    Schools in Yangon region saw less students on Monday, the first day of the reopening.    The authorities closed all schools since early July as part of the anti-pandemic measures.      The Ministry of Health has been administering Covid-19 vaccine doses to middle and high school students aged over 12 since Oct. 12.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220213221252/https://www.thestar.com.my/aseanplus/aseanplus-news/2021/11/01/myanmar-reopens-schools-amid-drop-in-new-covid-19-cases    https://web.archive.org/web/20220213221421/https://en.unesco.org/covid19/educationresponse

Many restrictions and policies that existed before the coup have not been formally rescinded. You are advised to follow local media for updates or check with your townships.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220213222136/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/myanmar/coronavirus    During COVID-19 stay-at-home orders in Burma, residents may only leave their residence to travel to/from work, to buy groceries, or for medical treatment.
