The country is currently in Phase 3:  - All educational institutions are closed  - All learning activities are to be conducted virtually    https://web.archive.org/web/20211014120833/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/sarawak/index-en.html

The country is currently in Phase 3:  - Private sector: Operational capacity limited to 80% at any one time, for business sectors allowed to operate  - Agricultural and commodities sector may operate at full capacity  *Only fully vaccinated workers are allowed to operate in premises    https://web.archive.org/web/20211014120833/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/sarawak/index-en.html

The country is currently in Phase 3:  - Live performances and events are allowed without an audience    https://web.archive.org/web/20211014120833/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/sarawak/index-en.html
The country is currently in Phase 3:  - All social activities and visitations are not allowed    https://web.archive.org/web/20211014120833/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/sarawak/index-en.html

Are commercial flights operating? Yes  Is public transportation operating? Yes  Masks must be worn on public transportation.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220129101556/https://my.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

The country is currently in Phase 3:  - Number of people in a car is determined by the car's capacity    https://web.archive.org/web/20211014120833/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/sarawak/index-en.html

The country is currently in Phase 3:  - Travelling between districts of the same state are allowed    Fully Vaccinated Individuals:  - Travelling to districts / states / country and tourism bubble areas is allowed  - Vehicles may carry passengers at full capacity    https://web.archive.org/web/20211014120833/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/sarawak/index-en.html

All travelers must undergo COVID-19 testing and most must quarantine at a facility designated by the Malaysian government.  The full cost of testing and quarantine must be borne by the traveler.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220129101556/https://my.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

PSU 4.0 will be implemented over four months from Aug 1, 2021. A total allocation of RM3.8 billion (896.6 million USD) would be channelled to qualified employers and limited to 500 workers for each company.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211226111920/https://www.mof.gov.my/portal/en/news/press-citations/govt-allocates-rm3-8-bln-for-4-month-psu-4-0-from-aug-1-tengku-zafrul

Bank Negara Malaysia (Central Bank of Malaysia) provides loan repayment assistance:  Moratorium for 6 months.  No supporting documentation required.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211226111954/https://www.bnm.gov.my/RA
The government has a dedicated website for COVID-19.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220129102417/https://covid--19-moh-gov-my.translate.goog/?_x_tr_sl=ms&_x_tr_tl=en&_x_tr_hl=en&_x_tr_pto=nui%2Csc

Self-administered Testing kits are now also available to be ordered from the government website and have been since 21st June.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211018160735/https://covid--19-moh-gov-my.translate.goog/garis-panduan/gp-umum-covid19/kit-ujian-kendiri-covid19-self-test-kit?_x_tr_sl=ms&_x_tr_tl=en&_x_tr_hl=en&_x_tr_pto=nui%2Csc

The use of the MySejethera app is not mandated but generally used across Malaysia for many functions including booking vaccinations and tracking social movements.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211226113805/https://mysejahtera.malaysia.gov.my/intro_en/
Facial coverings are required in Malaysia.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220129102803/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/malaysia/coronavirus

Vaccinations are freely available and fully funded by the government for all citizens and even foreign residents.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211225105249/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-malaysia-vaccines-idUSKBN2AB0E1

The country is currently in Phase 3:  "3 people in a household may go out (non-fully vaccinated)" in phase 3 regions, but did not specify elderly or not.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211014120833/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/sarawak/index-en.html

PHASE 3(May 2021 â February 2022)  Adult population aged 18 years and above (citizens & noncitizens)  Priority will be given to those in the red zones; followed by those  in yellow zones and finally those in green zones  Registration for the vaccine, which will start on the 1st of March 2021, will be implemented  through the website www.vaksincovid.gov.my    https://web.archive.org/web/20211012103539/https://www.vaksincovid.gov.my/pdf/National_COVID-19_Immunisation_Programme.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20211225104348/https://www.vaksincovid.gov.my/en/guide/?myshj

The government is targeting at least 60% of teenagers to receive at least one vaccination dose by November, with the aim of having 80% of teenagers fully vaccinated by next January.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210930161720/https://www.thestar.com.my/news/nation/2021/09/23/covid-19-over-half-a-million-adolescents-received-at-least-one-vaccine-dose-says-khairy
Both citizens and foreigners receive free vaccination.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210424042948/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-malaysia-vaccines-idUSKBN2AB0E1

New Zealand moves to Red at 11:59pm on 23 January, after 9 cases in the Nelson/Marlborough region were confirmed as the Omicron variant.    Tertiary students with a My Vaccine Pass will be able to attend classes, lectures, labs, workshops, tutorials and meetings in person. They can access research spaces, student support and advisory services.    Capacity is based on 1-metre distancing.    Without My Vaccine Pass  Tertiary students who do not have My Vaccine Pass should talk to their provider about alternative learning options.    http://web.archive.org/web/20220123034231/https://covid19.govt.nz/news-and-data/latest-news/nz-to-move-to-red/    http://web.archive.org/web/20220125103759/https://covid19.govt.nz/traffic-lights/life-at-red/education-at-red/tertiary-education-at-red/

New Zealand moves to Red at 11:59pm on 23 January, after 9 cases in the Nelson/Marlborough region were confirmed as the Omicron variant.    Most businesses can choose whether they require My Vaccine Pass for customers and visitors, but there will be restrictions if they do not, including possibly needing to close.    http://web.archive.org/web/20220123034231/https://covid19.govt.nz/news-and-data/latest-news/nz-to-move-to-red/    http://web.archive.org/web/20220120164519mp_/https://covid19.govt.nz/traffic-lights/life-at-red/businesses-and-workplaces-at-red/

New Zealand moves to Red at 11:59pm on 23 January, after 9 cases in the Nelson/Marlborough region were confirmed as the Omicron variant.    If an event organiser chooses to follow My Vaccine Pass requirements, only people with My Vaccine Pass are allowed to be there- therefore coded as a closure to non-vaccinated    http://web.archive.org/web/20220108144056mp_/https://covid19.govt.nz/traffic-lights/life-at-red/events-and-public-facilities-at-red/events-at-red/      http://web.archive.org/web/20220123034231/https://covid19.govt.nz/news-and-data/latest-news/nz-to-move-to-red/

New Zealand moves to Red at 11:59pm on 23 January, after 9 cases in the Nelson/Marlborough region were confirmed as the Omicron variant.    Without a vaccine pass - at a gathering at your home, there can be up to 25 people.    With my vaccine pass- At a gathering at your home or private dwelling, there can be up to 100 people.      http://web.archive.org/web/20211220210032mp_/https://covid19.govt.nz/traffic-lights/life-at-red/gatherings-and-visits-at-red/public-and-private-gatherings-at-red/    http://web.archive.org/web/20220123034231/https://covid19.govt.nz/news-and-data/latest-news/nz-to-move-to-red/

You do not need to show a vaccine pass to use public transport, as these services are needed to access services for basic needs such as food and healthcare.    There are no physical distancing requirements on public transport, at bus stops or train stations.    http://web.archive.org/web/20220123080144/https://covid19.govt.nz/traffic-lights/life-at-red/travel-and-accommodation-at-red/travel-at-red/

Between 15 December 2021 and 17 January 2022, you can travel into and out of Auckland for any reason but you must follow some restrictions to leave Auckland.    When leaving Auckland, no matter how long you have been inside the boundary:    you must have your My Vaccine Pass with you, or  you must carry evidence of a negative COVID-19 test taken no more than 72 hours before crossing the boundary.    You will need to show your My Vaccine Pass or a negative COVID-19 test taken no more than 72 hours before crossing the boundary to enter Northland. As this is an LFT requirement not PCR, coded as a 1 after targeted restrictions focused on Auckland end    http://web.archive.org/web/20220108145518mp_/https://covid19.govt.nz/traffic-lights/life-at-red/travel-and-accommodation-at-red/travel-at-red/    http://web.archive.org/web/20220123034231/https://covid19.govt.nz/news-and-data/latest-news/nz-to-move-to-red/

New Zealand moves to Red at 11:59pm on 23 January, after 9 cases in the Nelson/Marlborough region were confirmed as the Omicron variant.    You must wear a face covering on flights, public transport, and taxis, in retail shops and public venues, and in health and education facilities.    http://web.archive.org/web/20220123034231/https://covid19.govt.nz/news-and-data/latest-news/nz-to-move-to-red/    http://web.archive.org/web/20220125101644/https://covid19.govt.nz/traffic-lights/life-at-red/

From January 17, 2022, COVID-19 immunisation starts for 5 to 11-year-old tamariki, the specific vaccine being administered is Pfizer.    Everyone in New Zealand aged 5 or over can get a free COVID-19 vaccine. It does not matter what your visa or citizenship status is.    Pfizer is the preferred COVID-19 vaccine for use in New Zealand.  If you are 18 years of age or older and either you cannot get the Pfizer vaccine or you want a different option, you can get the AstraZeneca vaccine.  https://archive.fo/qjXZ6    https://archive.fo/iV2vX

22/1/22  gov.uk  From 17 January 2022, only fully vaccinated persons will be permitted to ride on public transportation in Metro Manila. All schools reopened on Jan 31 after Dec break. There is no news of any school closures or restrictions.

An official national curfew not currently in place, but business operations may be limited to prescribed hours. Officials allow restaurants and gambling establishments to operate under strict health requirements.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220205205616/https:/crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/02/papua-new-guinea-officials-adjust-covid-19-entry-restrictions-nationwide-tighter-domestic-measures-continue-through-feb-28-update-45    https://web.archive.org/web/20220120182508/https:/pg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

All gatherings of more than 100 people are prohibited starting Jan 14th to Feb 28th. This includes both social events and religious gatherings.    All gatherings between 20 and 100 people require permission from the National Control Center.    https://archive.vn/WhNra    https://web.archive.org/web/20220205205616/https:/crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/02/papua-new-guinea-officials-adjust-covid-19-entry-restrictions-nationwide-tighter-domestic-measures-continue-through-feb-28-update-45

All gatherings of more than 100 people are prohibited starting Jan 14th to Feb 28th. This includes both social and religious gatherings.    All gatherings between 20 and 100 people require permission from the National Control Center.    https://archive.vn/WhNra    https://web.archive.org/web/20220205205616/https:/crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/02/papua-new-guinea-officials-adjust-covid-19-entry-restrictions-nationwide-tighter-domestic-measures-continue-through-feb-28-update-45

The government limits capacity on public transport services. Police have threatened to impound any vehicle that violates capacity limits, though compliance and enforcement vary.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220205205616/https:/crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/02/papua-new-guinea-officials-adjust-covid-19-entry-restrictions-nationwide-tighter-domestic-measures-continue-through-feb-28-update-45    https://web.archive.org/web/20220120182508/https:/pg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
There are no stay-at-home requirements

Fully vaccinated travellers may travel within Papua New Guinea without restrictions except to/from high-risk areas. Effective October 13, 2021, the NCC has designated Western, Sandaun (West Sepik), Eastern Highlands, Western Highlands, Morobe, Chimbu, Enga, Hela, Jiwaka, and Southern as âhigh-riskâ provinces, and will implement restrictions on public or religious gatherings, public venues, and domestic passenger movements on aircraft into/within/from these provinces.  The only pre-approved travel into/within/from âhigh-riskâ provinces will be for health workers, business travel, and students.     Unvaccinated travellers must have one of the following valid purposes of travel:        Students returning to their usual place of residence or returning to their educational institutions;      Return to a habitual place of residence;      Essential business travel;      Medical assistance, emergencies, or medivac;      Emergency transport, including but not limited to repatriation of deceased persons;      Persons who have approval from the Controller, the Controllerâs delegate, or the provincial administrator from the travelerâs province of origin. Travellers should consult with their respective airline(s) prior to travel.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220120182508/https:/pg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Fully vaccinated citizens, permanent residents, and foreign nationals can enter the country with written approval from the National Pandemic Controller's Office; tourist travel remains banned.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220205205616/https:/crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/02/papua-new-guinea-officials-adjust-covid-19-entry-restrictions-nationwide-tighter-domestic-measures-continue-through-feb-28-update-45    https://web.archive.org/web/20220120182508/https:/pg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
No change in policy    https://web.archive.org/web/20220103200822/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19#P
No change in policy    https://web.archive.org/web/20220103200822/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19#P
There is a co-ordinated public health campaign    https://web.archive.org/web/20211031023630/https:/covid19.info.gov.pg/

Symptomatic persons are generally able to obtain free or government-subsidized testing services at Port Moresby General Hospital, the Taurama Aquatic Center, and other public clinics in Port Moresby. Testing services outside of Port Moresby may be obtained at provincial hospitals and other health facilities.     Non-symptomatic persons and persons wanting expedited results may obtain services through private medical facilities, including:        2K Medical Clinic      Pacific International Hospital      ASPEN Medical      Sky Health Medical Services      International SOS    Testing conducted through private medical facilities may cost as much as 250 USD.    Though electronic test results from such facilities are generally available within 24-72 hours upon request    https://web.archive.org/web/20220120182508/https:/pg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
Contact tracing is being done    https://web.archive.org/web/20220122215144/https:/covid19.info.gov.pg/situation-reports-2/

People 12 years old or above must wear facemasks in public places, except childcare centers and banks.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220205205616/https:/crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/02/papua-new-guinea-officials-adjust-covid-19-entry-restrictions-nationwide-tighter-domestic-measures-continue-through-feb-28-update-45

Vaccines are available for anyone above age 18.    Vaccines being given include Astra Zeneca, Johnson and Johnson and Sinopharm    https://web.archive.org/web/20220122215144/https:/covid19.info.gov.pg/situation-reports-2/
Booster doses of vaccine have been prioritized for the elderly    https://archive.vn/WhNra

Vaccines are available for anyone over the age of 18    On Jan 17th, booster doses were approved for those with underlying health conditions, immunocompromised and the elderly.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211031023630/https:/covid19.info.gov.pg/    https://archive.vn/WhNra

As of Jan 09, over 227,213 people are fully vaccinated in PNG and over 289,244 people have been vaccinated with at least 1 dose.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220122215144/https:/covid19.info.gov.pg/situation-reports-2/
Vaccines are fully funded by the government    https://web.archive.org/web/20211031023630/https:/covid19.info.gov.pg/

No coding changes for the period of 18-28 January 2022.  School continues to be in session with no reports of any closures, although Covid safety measurements are still in place (1).  The national vaccine programme has been extended to children between 5-11 years old, but no vaccine differentiated measures are in place for this age group.  _______________________    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20220128143718/https://www.moe.gov.sg/search?q=%2A&app=site_search&fq=content_type_s%3A%28%22news%22%29&sort=modified_dt+desc  _______________________    Quote (2):  "The Ministry of Education (MOE) and the Early Childhood Development Agency (ECDA) will be working with the Ministry of Health (MOH) to extend the national vaccination programme to cover over 300,000 children aged 5 to 11, starting with the older children from 27 December 2021. "    Link (2): http://web.archive.org/web/20220128144057/https://www.moe.gov.sg/news/press-releases/20211221-protecting-our-children-from-covid-19-with-vaccination-for-5-to-11-year-olds  ______________________    Quote (3):  "SINGAPORE: There are presently no plans to introduce vaccination-differentiated safe management measures for children aged 12 years and below, the Ministry of Health (MOH) said on Tuesday (Dec 14)."    Link (3): http://web.archive.org/web/20220128143711/https://www.channelnewsasia.com/singapore/no-plans-vaccination-differentiated-measures-children-covid-19-2378831

From 15 January 2022 onwards, a vaccine mandate for workers is implemented in order to be able to return to work places. Negative tests are no longer accepted for those unvaccinated.  A grace period for partially vaccinated individuals is in place until 31 January 2022.    50% of employees are now allowed back to the workplaces at any given point in time; although, they must adhere to the vaccine mandate as afore mentioned.  ____________    Quote (1):  "Phase 2 (15 January 2022 onwards): Only employees who are fully vaccinated, certified to be medically ineligible or have recovered from COVID-19 within 180 days, can return to the workplace. The concession for unvaccinated employees to perform PET in lieu of being fully vaccinated will be removed, i.e. such employees will not be allowed to return to the workplace even if they did PET with a negative result. Partially vaccinated7 employees will still be allowed at workplaces with a negative PET result up to 31 January 2022 after which they must be fully vaccinated."    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20220128135348/https://www.mom.gov.sg/covid-19/advisory-on-covid-19-vaccination-in-employment-settings  ___________    Quote (2):  "The following measures are put in place to slow the rate of transmission and minimise strain on our healthcare capacity.  From 1 January 2022, more employees3 are allowed to return to the workplace.  Up to 50% of employees who are able to work from home can be at the workplace at any point in time. For example, a company with 100 employees who can work from home can have up to 50 of these employees at the workplace at any point in time."    Link (2): http://web.archive.org/web/20220103082447/https://www.mom.gov.sg/covid-19/requirements-for-safe-management-measures

Vaccine differentiated measures are currently in place with only vaccinated individuals allowed into events. Current Covid safety measurements still prevail in all settings.  _________________    Quote (1):  " From 1 January 2022, the concession for unvaccinated individuals to perform PET in lieu of being fully vaccinated will be removed. Only fully vaccinated, recovered, or medically ineligible individuals, or children aged 12 years and below (subject to venue/event specific caps) will be allowed to enter settings where VDS is implemented."    "ATTRACTIONS,SHOWS & CRUISES  Entry allowed only if vaccinated.    CONGREGATIONAL & WORSHIP SERVICES  All vaccinated^ : Up to 1,000 worshippers.  Vaccinated performers or speakers may be unmasked, including for singing or playing of wind instruments at live performances.    MARRIAGE SOLEMNISATIONS  All vaccinated^ : Up to 1,000 attendees.    MUSEUMS & PUBLIC LIBRARIES  Entry allowed only if vaccinated."    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20220128150314/https://www.moh.gov.sg/covid-19-phase-advisory  __________________    Quote (2):  "(D) Expanding VDS to More Venues    10. Vaccination is key to protecting our population even as SMMs are further relaxed. From 1 December 2021, we will expand VDS to more settings and activities, including in all Libraries under the National Library Board (NLB), and selected activities in community clubs/centres under Peopleâs Association (PA). By restricting entry to only individuals who have been fully vaccinated, we can further reduce the risk of transmission in such settings.     11. A summary of the updated community measures from 22 November 2021 can be found in Annex A.     (E) Removal of VDS Concession for Voluntarily Unvaccinated Individuals     12. We will further strengthen efforts to protect unvaccinated individuals from getting infected, as they are subject to greater risks of severe illness. Under current rules, unvaccinated individuals can get a PET and show a negative test result to enter a VDS setting. We will remove this concession for unvaccinated individuals to perform PET in lieu of being fully vaccinated.  Hence, only fully vaccinated, recovered, or medically ineligible individuals, or children aged 12 years and below (subject to venue/event-specific caps) will be allowed to enter settings where VDS is implemented. We will effect this on 1 January 2022, to allow time for more individuals to complete their primary series vaccination regime. "    Link (2): http://web.archive.org/web/20220116160914/https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/resuming-our-transition-towards-covid-resilience

no coding changes to the period of 18-28 January 2022.  ____________________  *** Please see previous notes dated 17 January 2022:    No coding changes for the period of 07-17 January 2022.  All restrictions will remain the same all the way to and during the Chinese New Year (CNY) period in Early to mid February 2022.    Link [1]: http://archive.today/2022.01.17-030005/https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/health/current-covid-19-rules-will-stay-during-cny-period-in-view-of-omicron-wave-lawrence-wong  Link [2]: http://archive.today/2022.01.17-030048/https://www.todayonline.com/singapore/no-plans-relax-covid-19-curbs-chinese-new-year-holidays-lawrence-wong-1784181  Link [3]: http://archive.today/2022.01.17-030109/https://www.businesstimes.com.sg/government-economy/we-dont-intend-to-relax-further-says-lawrence-wong-as-covid-curbs-look-set-to  Link [4]: http://archive.today/2022.01.17-030130/https://www.gov.sg/article/safe-management-measures-and-chinese-new-year  ____________________  *** Please refer to previous notes:    No Coding Changes to the period of 01-06 January 2022. Recent updates from the government states that in light of the Omicron variant, the current Covid-19 safety measurements will remain unchanged right into the Chinese New Year (CNY) period - this commences on the 01-02 February 2022 and normally the period stretches for 14 days.  ________________________    Quote (1):  "SINGAPORE - Singapore's current set of Covid-19 safe management rules will stay in place during the upcoming Chinese New Year period from Feb 1, in view of a likely surge of infections brought about by the new Omicron variant, said Finance Minister Lawrence Wong on Wednesday (Jan 5). Group sizes for gathering and dining at restaurants have been capped at five since November, when Singapore emerged from an outbreak caused by the earlier Delta variant. Mr Wong, who is a co-chair of the multi-ministry task force handling Covid-19, said during a press conference that the present posture would be maintained as he could not imagine the Omicron wave passing before Chinese New Year."    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20220106084209/https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/health/current-covid-19-rules-will-stay-during-cny-period-in-view-of-omicron-wave-lawrence-wong.    ______________________    ***Please also refer to notes dated 18 Dec 2021:  No Coding changes to the period of 14-18 Dec.   _____________  ***Please refer to notes dated 19 Nov 2021:    No coding changes for the period of 07-19 Nov 2021 [Link (1)]. Covid safety measures in place but no reduction to services country-wide [Link(1)].    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20211119095744/https://www.lta.gov.sg/content/ltagov/en/industry_innovations/industry_matters/LTA%27s%20Measures%20for%20COVID-19.html

Group sizes for gathering and dining at restaurants have been capped at five since November, when Singapore emerged from an outbreak caused by the earlier Delta variant. Mr Wong, who is a co-chair of the multi-ministry task force handling Covid-19, said during a press conference that the present posture would be maintained as he could not imagine the Omicron wave passing before Chinese New Year." Vaccine differentiated measures for travelers to Singapore have been in place for many months and have recently increased to include a mandate for work passes. There are a few exceptions but these might require pre-approval but a government body.  _______________________    Quote (1):  "Persons who are medically unfit to be vaccinated are not allowed to travel under the VTL (Air).  Unvaccinated short-term visitors will not be allowed to travel to Singapore.    However, unvaccinated:  Singapore Citizens  Permanent Residents, and  Long-Term Pass holders who have received entry approval via the SC/PR Familial Ties Lane  may still travel to Singapore on a non-designated flight. They will be subject to the prevailing Stay-Home Notice (SHN) and COVID-19 test requirements upon entry into Singapore.    3. What must travellers present as their proof of vaccination at check-in and arrival immigration?  I am a...	My proof of vaccination was issued...	I will need to present...  Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident	In Singapore	Either a valid vaccination status on the TraceTogether or HealthHub app or a vaccination certificate issued by the Singapore Ministry of Health.  Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident	Overseas	One of the accepted proof of vaccination, which may include your overseas-issued vaccination certificate  Long-Term Pass Holder or Short-Term Visitor	In Singapore	A valid Vaccinated Travel Pass (Air) [VTP (Air)], which you can apply for here*. Please click here for more details.  Long-Term Pass Holder or Short-Term Visitor	Overseas	  A valid Vaccinated Travel Pass (Air) [VTP (Air)], which you can apply for here*, and an accepted proof of vaccination, if necessary.    *On the VTP (Air) application portal, please select one of the following options depending on your pass type:  MOM Long-Term Pass Holder if you are a holder of an Employment Pass, Work Pass, Dependentâs Pass, MOM Long-Term Visit Pass, etc.; or  MOE Long-Term Pass Holder if you are a Student Pass holder."    Link (1): http://archive.today/2022.01.28-152708/https://safetravel.ica.gov.sg/vtl/faq  _____________________    Quote (2):  "Covid Vaccination Mandatory In Singapore From February 2022  Singapore: Singapore has made Covid vaccination a mandatory condition for the approval of new applications for work passes, long-term passes and permanent residence in Singapore from February 1 next year. Those renewing their work passes will also have to be vaccinated, The Straits Times reported, citing the multi-ministry task force (MMTF) on Covid."    Link (2): http://web.archive.org/web/20220128152404/https://www.ndtv.com/world-news/coronavirus-covid-vaccination-mandatory-in-singapore-from-february-2022-2673179  ____________________    Quote (3):  "Calibrating Vaccinated Travel Lane (VTL) Testing Regimes    24.    On 31 December 2021, we announced a four-week extension to the enhanced 7- day testing regime for travellers arriving via VTLs in order to facilitate the detection of imported Omicron cases and slow transmission into the community. This has bought time for us to booster vaccinate more residents, learn more about the Omicron variant and make necessary adjustments to our COVID-19 strategy. As imported cases now form a shrinking proportion of our overall cases, we will simplify the VTL testing regime.    25.     These measures are less relevant now. Hence, VTL travellers entering Singapore after 23 January 2022, 2359 hours via both air and land checkpoints will only be required to do unsupervised self-administered ARTs from Day 2 to Day 7 of their arrivals if they need to leave their place of residence or accommodation. Travellers need not submit their ART results but must test negative before going out. VTL travellers who arrive before 23 January 2022, 2359 hours are still required to continue with the existing testing regime (i.e. unsupervised self-administered ART on Days 2, 4, 5 and 6 with submission of results online, and supervised ART on Days 3 and 7 from their arrival).    26.    Travellers who test positive on ARTs (i.e. the on-arrival test for VTL-Land and unsupervised self-administered ARTs on Days 2 to 7) no longer need to undergo a confirmatory PCR test, but should instead simply recover under Protocol 2.2 That said, those who identify themselves as potentially at risk (as stipulated in Annex C) should visit a doctor for medical advice after testing positive even if they feel well.    27.     We will continue to maintain a 50% limit on VTL flight and bus tickets for entry into Singapore for now. We will continue to review the local and global COVID-19 situation and adjust our measures accordingly.    Facilitating Travel for Recently-Recovered Travellers    28.    With the growing number of cases worldwide, there is a rise in the number of travellers who have recently recovered from COVID-19. Such travellers can continue to shed non-infectious viral fragments even after they have recovered, and therefore test positive for COVID-19 despite posing no infection risk. As fully vaccinated individuals who recently recovered from infection have a high level of immunity through their recent COVID-19 infection and vaccination, the likelihood of reinfection is low.    29.     Hence, travellers arriving after 23 January 2022, 2359 hours who are fully vaccinated and recently recovered (i.e. within 90 days of their last infection) will be exempted from all testing and SHN requirements if they are able to provide appropriate documentary proof. Non-fully vaccinated recently-recovered travellers will be exempted from pre-departure testing requirements, but will still be subjected to all other prevailing border measures. This will facilitate the safe return of recently-recovered residents who travel overseas. See Annex D for the list of documentation to be presented by such travellers at check-in and arrival immigration to qualify for this exemption."    Link (3): http://archive.today/2022.01.28-152933/https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/focusing-our-resources-and-refining-our-healthcare-protocols-to-deal-with-the-omicron-wave

Long-Term Pass Holder or Short-Term Visitor	Overseas	  A valid Vaccinated Travel Pass (Air) [VTP (Air)], which you can apply for here*, and an accepted proof of vaccination, if necessary.    *On the VTP (Air) application portal, please select one of the following options depending on your pass type:  MOM Long-Term Pass Holder if you are a holder of an Employment Pass, Work Pass, Dependentâs Pass, MOM Long-Term Visit Pass, etc.; or  MOE Long-Term Pass Holder if you are a Student Pass holder."    Link (1): http://archive.today/2022.01.28-152708/https://safetravel.ica.gov.sg/vtl/faq  _____________________    Quote (2):  "Covid Vaccination Mandatory In Singapore From February 2022  Singapore: Singapore has made Covid vaccination a mandatory condition for the approval of new applications for work passes, long-term passes and permanent residence in Singapore from February 1 next year. Those renewing their work passes will also have to be vaccinated, The Straits Times reported, citing the multi-ministry task force (MMTF) on Covid."    Link (2): http://web.archive.org/web/20220128152404/https://www.ndtv.com/world-news/coronavirus-covid-vaccination-mandatory-in-singapore-from-february-2022-2673179  ____________________    Quote (3):  "Calibrating Vaccinated Travel Lane (VTL) Testing Regimes    24.    On 31 December 2021, we announced a four-week extension to the enhanced 7- day testing regime for travellers arriving via VTLs in order to facilitate the detection of imported Omicron cases and slow transmission into the community. This has bought time for us to booster vaccinate more residents, learn more about the Omicron variant and make necessary adjustments to our COVID-19 strategy. As imported cases now form a shrinking proportion of our overall cases, we will simplify the VTL testing regime.    25.     These measures are less relevant now. Hence, VTL travellers entering Singapore after 23 January 2022, 2359 hours via both air and land checkpoints will only be required to do unsupervised self-administered ARTs from Day 2 to Day 7 of their arrivals if they need to leave their place of residence or accommodation. Travellers need not submit their ART results but must test negative before going out. VTL travellers who arrive before 23 January 2022, 2359 hours are still required to continue with the existing testing regime (i.e. unsupervised self-administered ART on Days 2, 4, 5 and 6 with submission of results online, and supervised ART on Days 3 and 7 from their arrival).    26.    Travellers who test positive on ARTs (i.e. the on-arrival test for VTL-Land and unsupervised self-administered ARTs on Days 2 to 7) no longer need to undergo a confirmatory PCR test, but should instead simply recover under Protocol 2.2 That said, those who identify themselves as potentially at risk (as stipulated in Annex C) should visit a doctor for medical advice after testing positive even if they feel well.    27.     We will continue to maintain a 50% limit on VTL flight and bus tickets for entry into Singapore for now. We will continue to review the local and global COVID-19 situation and adjust our measures accordingly.    Facilitating Travel for Recently-Recovered Travellers    28.    With the growing number of cases worldwide, there is a rise in the number of travellers who have recently recovered from COVID-19. Such travellers can continue to shed non-infectious viral fragments even after they have recovered, and therefore test positive for COVID-19 despite posing no infection risk. As fully vaccinated individuals who recently recovered from infection have a high level of immunity through their recent COVID-19 infection and vaccination, the likelihood of reinfection is low.    29.     Hence, travellers arriving after 23 January 2022, 2359 hours who are fully vaccinated and recently recovered (i.e. within 90 days of their last infection) will be exempted from all testing and SHN requirements if they are able to provide appropriate documentary proof. Non-fully vaccinated recently-recovered travellers will be exempted from pre-departure testing requirements, but will still be subjected to all other prevailing border measures. This will facilitate the safe return of recently-recovered residents who travel overseas. See Annex D for the list of documentation to be presented by such travellers at check-in and arrival immigration to qualify for this exemption."    Link (3): http://archive.today/2022.01.28-152933/https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/focusing-our-resources-and-refining-our-healthcare-protocols-to-deal-with-the-omicron-wave

In additon, the government announced SGD$130 million (Approx USD$ 95 million) stimuli in the form of cash vouchers that can be utilized at select merchants across the country,    ___________________  Quote (1):  "SINGAPORE - All Singaporean households can now collect $100 worth of vouchers that they can spend at about 10,000 participating hawkers and heartland merchants.    The community development council (CDC) vouchers, worth $130 million in total and given out to 1.3 million households, are available for collection digitally from Monday (Dec 13) and can be used till Dec 31, 2022."    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20211213094222/https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/100-worth-of-cdc-vouchers-for-each-sporean-household-available-for-collection-online  ________________    Quote (2): [Exchange Rate]  "Dec 13, 2021 09:38 UTC  Singapore Dollar	130,000,000.00 SGD	  US Dollar	95035922.924214	@ 1.367904"    Link (2): https://web.archive.org/web/20211213094242/https://www.x-rates.com/historical/?from=SGD&amount=130000000&date=2021-12-13  ______________    ***Please also refer to notes dated 19 Nov 2021:    No coding changes for the period of 07-19 Nov 2021.     ____________________________________  ****Please refer to previous notes dated 6 Nov 2021:    no coding changes to the period of 02-06 Nov 2021.   ___________________  ***Please refer to notes dates 01 Nov 2021:    No coding changes for the period of 24 Oct -01 Nov.  ___________________  *** Please refer to notes dates 23 Oct 2021    Support to continue until Nov 21 in light of the further extensions of the current restrictions.  ___________________    Quote (1):  "SINGAPORE: A S$640 million support package will be rolled out for affected businesses and workers, after it was announced on Wednesday (Oct 20) that Singapore will extend its COVID-19 restrictions by nearly a month.  The stabilisation phase, which started on Sep 27 to help reduce the strain on the healthcare system, was scheduled to last until Oct 24.   It has now been extended until Nov 21, with a review of the measures at the two-week mark. They may be adjusted based on the situation then, said the Ministry of Health (MOH) in a media release.  During the stabilisation phase, social gatherings and dining-in have been capped at groups of two, while work-from-home has been the default arrangement.  Given the extended restrictions, the Government will continue with the Jobs Support Scheme until Nov 21, at 25 per cent wage support for sectors significantly affected by the tightened measures.  These include F&B, retail, cinemas, museums and art galleries, family entertainment, tourism, gyms and fitness studios, as well as performing arts and arts education.  A two-week rental waiver will be given to qualifying tenants on government-owned commercial properties.  Eligible tenant-occupiers and owner-occupiers of privately-owned commercial properties will also be given a 0.5-month rental relief cash payout under the Rental Support Scheme (RSS).  Cooked food and market stallholders in centres managed by the National Environment Agency (NEA) or operators appointed by NEA will receive a 0.5-month rental waiver.    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20211023041636/https://www.channelnewsasia.com/singapore/covid-19-support-package-jobs-support-scheme-extended-restrictions-2257036

no coding changes to the period of 18-28 January 2022.  ____________  ***Please refer to previous notes dates 17 January 2022.    No coding changes for the period of 07-17 January 2022.  All restrictions will remain the same all the way to and during the Chinese New Year (CNY) period in Early to mid February 2022.    Link [1]: http://archive.today/2022.01.17-030005/https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/health/current-covid-19-rules-will-stay-during-cny-period-in-view-of-omicron-wave-lawrence-wong  Link [2]: http://archive.today/2022.01.17-030048/https://www.todayonline.com/singapore/no-plans-relax-covid-19-curbs-chinese-new-year-holidays-lawrence-wong-1784181  Link [3]: http://archive.today/2022.01.17-030109/https://www.businesstimes.com.sg/government-economy/we-dont-intend-to-relax-further-says-lawrence-wong-as-covid-curbs-look-set-to  Link [4]: http://archive.today/2022.01.17-030130/https://www.gov.sg/article/safe-management-measures-and-chinese-new-year  ____________________  *** Please refer to previous notes:    No Coding Changes to the period of 01-06 January 2022. Recent updates from the government states that in light of the Omicron variant, the current Covid-19 safety measurements will remain unchanged right into the Chinese New Year (CNY) period - this commences on the 01-02 February 2022 and normally the period stretches for 14 days.  ________________________    Quote (1):  "SINGAPORE - Singapore's current set of Covid-19 safe management rules will stay in place during the upcoming Chinese New Year period from Feb 1, in view of a likely surge of infections brought about by the new Omicron variant, said Finance Minister Lawrence Wong on Wednesday (Jan 5). Group sizes for gathering and dining at restaurants have been capped at five since November, when Singapore emerged from an outbreak caused by the earlier Delta variant. Mr Wong, who is a co-chair of the multi-ministry task force handling Covid-19, said during a press conference that the present posture would be maintained as he could not imagine the Omicron wave passing before Chinese New Year."    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20220106084209/https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/health/current-covid-19-rules-will-stay-during-cny-period-in-view-of-omicron-wave-lawrence-wong.    ______________________    ***Please also refer to notes dated 18 Dec 2021:  No coding changes for the period of 14-18 Dec 2021. _  __________   ***Please refer to notes dated 13 Dec 2021:  Face masks continue to be mandated any time outside of the home. _    ______________    Quote (1): ""How does COVID-19 spread? Current evidence suggests that transmission of COVID-19 occurs primarily through the respiratory droplets of infected people, which are expelled when an infected person coughs, sneezes, talks or sings. These respiratory droplets can reach the eyes, nose or mouth of a susceptible person directly or indirectly (via contaminated surfaces), resulting in infection.  Airborne transmission of the virus can occur in health care settings where aerosol-generating procedures are performed. While there have been limited reports of airborne transmission outside of health care settings internationally, its role and extent are under further study. MOH will continue to monitor the evidence as it emerges.  To reduce the risk of spread, members of public must wear a mask outside the home and observe safe distancing. Individuals should also observe good hand hygiene and avoid crowded spaces if possible.""      Link (1): https://web.archive.org/web/20211206075819/https://www.moh.gov.sg/covid-19/general

No coding changes for the period of 18-28 January 2022.  ___________________________________________  Universal availability for the initial regimen with booster shots allowed for prioritized groups [Link (2)]. The current validity duration of the initial vaccine regimen is under review - in order for individuals to maintain a ""fully vaccinated"" status, they may be required to take booster shots or to have a second regimen in a year's time [Link (3)]. Children under 12 are currently under review to possibly receive the vaccine in the future [Link (4)].  The government has recently announced that children from 5-11 years old are not able to take part in the national vaccination program. It campaign has not yet begun but is schedule to by the end of 2021. [Link (5)] .  Additionally, vaccines for children aged 5-11 years old are now eligible for the covid vaccine under the National Vaccination Programme. [Link (6)]    Groups: Universal availability    Vaccines:    1. Moderna (Government Funded)   2. Pfizer-BioNTech/Comirnaty (Government Funded)   3. Sinovac (partial Individual Cost through the Private sector OR Government funded) -SAR   4. Sinopharm (Government Funded/Individual cost through the Private sector only ) - SAR    5. AstraZeneca (Individual cost through the Private sector only ) - SAR      *SAR = Special Access Route ____________________________________      Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20211116203225/https://www.moh.gov.sg/covid-19/vaccination     Link (2): http://web.archive.org/web/20211014035410/https://www.channelnewsasia.com/singapore/covid-19-vaccine-booster-shots-seniors-immunocompromised-elderly-care-homes-2154791     Link (3): http://web.archive.org/web/20211112144700/https://www.channelnewsasia.com/singapore/covid19-vaccine-expiry-date-365-days-booster-moh-2308821     Link (4): http://web.archive.org/web/20211119083158/https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/kkh-recruiting-children-aged-5-to-11-for-covid-19-vaccination-trial     Link (5): http://web.archive.org/web/20211213092117/https://www.channelnewsasia.com/singapore/moh-covid-19-vaccination-children-singapore-2372631    Link (6): http://web.archive.org/web/20220102123050/https://www.moe.gov.sg/news/press-releases/20211221-protecting-our-children-from-covid-19-with-vaccination-for-5-to-11-year-olds

Regardless of vaccination status, there are strict rules for each group of individuals before being able to enter nursing homes and hospitals to visit the elderly.    From the 24 of January, all in-persons will be suspended for 4 weeks until 20 February 2022 in light of the current omicron wave in Singapore.  _________________    Quote (1):  "[Updated 21 January 2022]    To better protect our patients and healthcare workers, particularly in settings with vulnerable persons, in-person visits to all hospital wards1 and residential care homes will be suspended for a period of four weeks, from 24 January to 20 February 2022 (both dates inclusive).    During this period, hospitals and homes can make assessments on a case-by-case basis to allow in-person visits for exceptional cases. More details for visits to hospitals and homes can be found below.    Pre-visit testing requirements at hospitals and homes    Visitors who are allowed into hospital wards and homes will be required to show a valid negative ART result obtained within the last 24 hours of each visit. All tests are to be self-funded by the visitor. This is a mandatory requirement for all visitors regardless of vaccination status, except for persons who have recovered from COVID-19 and are able to present a valid Pre-Event Test (PET) exemption notice2.   Fully vaccinated or medically ineligible visitors can perform an unsupervised self-administered ART or opt for an ART administered by MOH-approved COVID-19 test providers (including tests performed at Quick Test Centres) to fulfil the pre-visit testing requirement. Those who opt to undergo unsupervised self-administered ART will be required to show evidence of a valid ART result, e.g. present a time-stamped photo of the dated ART result and photo ID for verification prior to entry.  Non-fully vaccinated visitors would be required to show results of ART administered or supervised by MOH-approved COVID-19 test providers (including Quick Test Centres). Results from unsupervised self-administered ART will not be accepted for this group of visitors.    In-person visits at hospitals  The following patient groups will continue to be allowed visitors on a case-by case basis, as assessed by the hospitals:   a. Patients who are in critical condition;    b. Paediatric patients;   c. Birthing/post-partum mothers; and    d. Patients requiring additional care support from caregivers. Examples of caregivers include those providing assistance to inpatients who have mental incapacities or family members who are undergoing caregiver training to better  care for their loved ones after hospital discharge.      The above patient groups would be allowed only one pre-designated visitor, with one visit per day. Patients who are in critical condition may be allowed up to five pre-designated visitors, with a maximum of two visitors at the patientâs bedside at any one time.  All visitors approved to enter hospital wards must don face masks with good filtration capability at all times. These include surgical masks and reusable masks that are made of two layers of fabric. Visitors are reminded not to eat or drink in the hospital wards or use the patientsâ toilets in the wards. They should also avoid sitting on patientsâ beds.    1Includes public acute hospitals, community hospitals and private hospitals   2 Recovered individuals (within last 180 days) can obtain a PET Exemption Notice from any clinic  offering ART or Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) testing services."    Link (1): http://web.archive.org/web/20220128155429/https://www.gov.sg/article/resuming-in-person-visits-to-hospitals-and-residential-care-homes  _______________    Quote (2):  "SINGAPORE - In-person visits to hospital wards and residential care homes will be suspended for the next four weeks amid a surge in Omicron Covid-19 cases over the past few weeks.  This is to protect Singapore's healthcare capacity and vulnerable seniors, the Ministry of Health (MOH) said on Friday (Jan 21). The suspension will last from next Monday (Jan 24) to Feb 20."    Link (2): http://web.archive.org/web/20220122211503/https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/health/visits-to-hospital-wards-nursing-homes-suspended-for-4-weeks-amid-covid-19-omicron-surge

Schools throughout the country will not start potentially for a month or more and any advice to begin classes will only come from the Ministry of Health and the COVID-19 Oversight Committee. Initially, the 2022 school year is to begin tomorrow but the COVID-19 outbreak in Honiara, Guadalcanal and Malaita has interrupted the new calendar year.    Dr Roddie said until they are advised by health authorities that it is safe to go back to school before they begin classes for 2022.  He said because of that students will remain at their homes and they will start the learning continuity programme.  The programme comprises lessons for ECE, primary, and secondary schools and will be broadcast on SIBC.  Dr Roddie admits that it would not be easy for those in remote areas who donât have access to quality radio reception. He confirms that the programme will start in early February.  The website was last updated on 23rd Jan 2022.    https://archive.vn/SpJLD

Following the lifting of the Lock-Down in Honiara on 6 am Sat 22 Jan 2022, the SIG-Public Service businesses will reopen on Mon 24 Jan 2022 with strict conditions as required by the SIG-MHMS Covid19 health and safety  The government recommend reactivating work-from-home arrangement to public servants who may unable to attend to duty office/place due to high risks by providing work-enabling ICT devices.     However, Crisis 24 an integrated security risk management company documented that almost all entertainment businesses and hospitality premises are closed; restaurants can offer takeaway services in Honiara.     https://archive.vn/xoY6z   https://archive.vn/d96y0

According to Crisis 24, a security website, the government requires people nationwide to follow social distancing measures. Officials require at least two meters (6.5 feet) of physical distance in public; however, enforcement is likely lax. A facemask requirement is also in place, but specific rules may vary by location. Officials are enacting tighter restrictions in areas with COVID-19 transmission. The government is implementing tight rules in the Honiara Emergency Zone, a designated area from Poha to Alligator Creek. Authorities are enforcing a nightly 17:00-08:00 curfew, though exceptions are possible for essential reasons. Gatherings of more than five people are banned.     According to the US Embassy website, as of January 31, a daily curfew from 5:00 p.m. through 8:00 a.m. is in effect for the Honiara Emergency Zone, until further notice.    https://archive.vn/d96y0  https://archive.vn/rVrhn

The US Embassy in Solomon Island stated on their website that public transportation is available but with strict limits on the number of passengers. All passengers must be fully vaccinated and carry a vaccination certificate.    https://archive.vn/rVrhn

The national government has reminded the public that no one is allowed to enter or leave the emergency zone according to the Order issued by the Prime Minister as of Sunday 30th January 2022.    In a statement to the media, the national government cited the Order as the Emergency Powers (COVID- 19) (Honiara Emergency Zone) (Restrictions of movements of people) (No.3) Order 2022 and is effective on Sunday 30th January 2022.    The governmentâs statement pointed out that the Honiara Emergency Zone is defined as from Alligator Creek in the East to Poha River on the West side of Honiara. Details of the boundary are represented in coordinates supplied with the Order.    The statement added that the Order provides that Honiara Emergency Zone is in lockdown which means that no person from outside the Honiara Emergency is allowed to enter or any person from inside the Honiara Emergency Zone allowed to exit the Honiara Emergency Zone.    âIn addition to that, the Order also spelt out clearly that on Sunday 30 January 2022 until the Order is revoked, a curfew exists between the hours of 5 pm until 8 am the next day and movement is only allowed between 8 am and 5 pm daily until revoked,â the national government added.    During the curfew hours of 5 pm â 8 am the next day, a person in the Honiara Emergency Zone must remain at his residence and not leave his place of residence.    https://archive.vn/CeZvV

21/1/22  Schools across Thailand are closed apart from those in Phuket. This order is valid until 31st January.    The Minister for Education recommended 'school from home' until January 14th. However, some provinces e.g. Phuket have encouraged schools to return to on-site learning     https://archive.vn/l2YUt

On 20th January 2022, the Ministry of Health issued guidance that it will not order schools to close unless clusters of Covid-19 cases turn up. Measures would also be targeted within the school; if cases are found, a particular classroom or grade might be ordered to close for cleaning for 3 days, rather than the entire school.      Additionally, the National News Bureau of Thailand reported on 18th January 2022 that many schools in Thailand have resumed onsite classes, but are also staggering the return of their students to reduce crowding. Some schools are for example, requiring some grades to remain fully online, while the rest of the students alternate the days that they attend in person, so that only 30% of the student body is present at any one time. Therefore, although many schools are open, significant public health precautions have been incorporated.     1.	The Nation | Thailand article: âNo school shutdowns unless clusters emergeâ: https://web.archive.org/web/20220124150009/https://www.nationthailand.com/in-focus/40011306  2.	National News Bureau of Thailand article: âSchools hold first on-site classes of 2022â: https://web.archive.org/web/20220124145222/https://thainews.prd.go.th/en/news/detail/TCATG220118165943585

According to a statement by the Thai Health Minister on 18th January 2022, the government has ordered entertainment venues catering to the nightlife to remain closed for the foreseeable future. While the government intends to relax restrictions in other economic sectors, it views these venues as being particularly high-risk for COVID-19 transmission.     Correlates with Tourism Authority of Thailand update on 23rd January 2022, stating that âall types of entertainment venues, including pubs, bars, and karaoke shops nationwide are to remain closed until further notice.â     It is noted that in practice, some of such venues have been able to re-open as ârestaurantsâ or âeateriesâ if they alter their services and meet certain government requirements. Other sources state that some entertainment venues that have not properly converted to restaurants have also re-opened illegally. Nonetheless coded as 2G to reflect official government policy, and because in practice, venues that do not have kitchen facilities are unable to legally convert to a restaurant.     1.	Tourism Authority of Thailand update: https://archive.vn/ft5i4  2.	ChannelNewsAsia article reporting on statement by Thai Health Minister: https://web.archive.org/web/20220123164614/https://www.channelnewsasia.com/asia/thailand-lower-covid-19-alert-level-2442896   3.	Thai PBS News article: https://web.archive.org/web/20220123163956/https://www.thaipbsworld.com/bangkok-announces-continued-closure-of-entertainment-venues/   4.	Thaiger article: https://web.archive.org/web/20220123165750/https://thethaiger.com/news/bangkok/bma-follows-ccsa-bangkok-entertainment-venues-remain-closed   5.	MixMag Asia article: âJanuary 16th has come and gone but most clubs in Thailand remain in the dark.â https://archive.vn/WsDqz

From 24 January, 2022, restaurants and eateries in the Blue Zone destinations that have received the SHA Plus certification (Ministry of Tourism and Sports) or the Thai Stop COVID 2 Plus standard (Ministry of Public Health) will be allowed to serve dine-in customers alcoholic beverages up until 23.00 Hrs.    However, all types of entertainment venues, including pubs, bars, and karaoke shops nationwide are to remain closed until further notice.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220124185839/https://www.tatnews.org/2022/01/thailand-adjusts-covid-19-curbs-nationwide-from-24-january-2022/

On 18th January 2022, the Bangkok Metropolitan Administration (BMA) announced that it will cancel the Chinese New Year celebrations that it normally organises at Bangkok's Yaowarat Road/Chinatown, due to concerns over the Omicron variant. However, apart from this specific government-organised event in Bangkok, have not found evidence of the BMA or other Thai authorities requiring other public events held by private actors to be cancelled.     The government offered safety tips for Chinese New Year, but there is no mention of a ban on public events. It is phrased as âadviceâ for people to generally avoid crowded places. Therefore, coded as 1G because there is a recommendation to avoid crowds, but without an actual requirement to cancel events.     Archived sources:   1. Thai Government Public Relations Department (official Facebook page) (English): https://archive.ph/OeRkH  2. Matichon Online Newspaper (Thai): https://archive.ph/aO9zp  3. The Nation | Thailand (English): "No Chinese New Year celebrations in Chinatown.": https://archive.ph/0a6Np   4. Thai PBS News (English): "Bangkok City Hall cancels Chinese New Year celebrations as Omicron spreads": https://archive.vn/BYsSo  5. Thai PBS News (English): "Safety tips from the Thai government for Chinese New Year celebrations." https://web.archive.org/web/20220122102014/https://www.thaipbsworld.com/safety-tips-from-the-thai-government-for-chinese-new-year-celebrations/

Thailand utilises a colour-coded zoning system for COVID-19 restrictions (From high restrictions to low: Dark Red, Red, Orange, Yellow, Blue). Presently, no provinces are classified dark red, red or yellow, but most provinces (69 out of 76) are classified in the orange zone for the period of 18thâ23rd January 2022. In orange zones, gatherings of no more than 500 people are permitted. Government announced on 20th January that it will relax restrictions and move 25 provinces from the orange to yellow zone, but this will only take effect on 24th January 2022.     Coded 2G; although some provinces are in the more relaxed blue zone (where restrictions have been eased with an eye on allowing the tourism sector to recover due to its importance to the Thai economy), the vast majority of provinces (69/76) have orange zone restrictions.     Archived sources:  1. Tourism Authority Thailand update stating that 69 provinces will be designated in the orange zone with effect from 9th January 2022: https://web.archive.org/web/20220122213830/https://www.tatnews.org/2022/01/thailand-steps-up-covid-19-curbs-nationwide-from-9-january-2022/  2. Bangkok Post article dated 21st January 2022, confirming that 69 provinces are presently in the orange zone, and that 25 provinces will be reclassified within the yellow zone from 24th January 2022: https://archive.vn/GIewc

Thailand uses a colour-coded zoning system for assigning COVID-19 restrictions to its 76 provinces and the Bangkok Special Administrative Area. These classifications, in the order of most restrictive to least restrictive are: dark red, red, orange, yellow and blue. Currently, no provinces are classified red or dark red. Restrictions on gatherings are as follow: orange â up to 500 people, yellow and blue â up to 1000 people.     With effect from 24th January 2022, the government has moved 25 provinces from the orange to yellow zone. 44 provinces remain classified in the orange zone, with the remainder in the blue zone. While it is important to note these zoning changes, the classification remains unchanged at 2G because gatherings are still restricted to no more than 1000 people nationwide.     Archived sources:  1.	Bangkok Post article, 21st January 2022: âCovid rules to ease as threat wanesâ: https://archive.vn/GIewc   2.	Garda Crisis24 Risk Management Report on Thailandâs most recent COVID-19 management measures: https://web.archive.org/web/20220124044026/https://crisis24.garda.com/insights-intelligence/intelligence/risk-alerts/wip10011892869/thailand-authorities-to-ease-covid-19-curbs-in-some-provinces-from-jan-24-resume-test-and-go-program-applications-from-feb-1-update-68

The Royal Thai Government maintained the designation of 8 âBlue Zoneâ provinces and 18 provinces with âBlue Zoneâ districts, while redesignating 25 provinces as Areas Under Stringent Surveillance or yellow zone and continued existing measures in 44 provinces as Controlled Areas or orange zone, effective from 24 January, 2022.    Meetings and events in hotels, trade centres, convention halls, and similar venues can be organised for less than 1,000 attendees, and under stringent disease prevention and control guidelines. Meanwhile, provinces in the orange zone can arrange more engaging activities; such as, sports tournaments, food fairs, and the like for no more than 1,000 attendees.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220124185839/https://www.tatnews.org/2022/01/thailand-adjusts-covid-19-curbs-nationwide-from-24-january-2022/

Have not found indications of any restrictions on public transport being imposed in recent Thai government announcements otherwise giving updates on planned changes to Covid-19 measures. By contrast, previous closures were announced and widely reported upon. Furthermore, public transport providers, such as the Bangkok Metro, have indicated they are operating normally, emphasising that commuters should cooperate with public health measures and minimise the spread of Covid-19 by wearing masks.     As of 24th January 2022, the UK Foreign Officeâs travel advice for Thailand only warns of potential disruptions to public transport due to political rallies, rather than Covid-19 management measures. Thai authorities will lift an entry ban on passengers arriving from Botswana, Eswatini, Lesotho, Malawi, Mozambique, Namibia, South Africa, and Zimbabwe from Jan. 11. https://archive.vn/sUA5H

For the period of 18thâ24th January 2022, quarantines are compulsory for travellers to Thailand. There are however, differentiated rules based on vaccination status, with stricter rules for unvaccinated people (the "Alternative Quarantine" scheme). Unvaccinated travellers to Thailand must quarantine for 10 days and undergo 2 PCR tests upon arrival. Before travelling to Thailand, a negative PCR test taken no earlier than 72 hours prior to departure is also required, except for travellers under the age of 6. Travellers from any country in the world can enter via this scheme.     Additional notes: Vaccinated travellers can undergo a shorter 7-day quarantine, but must also take pre-departure and post-arrival PCR tests. The Thai government has announced that it will further relax international travel controls, but these will come into effect only on 1st February 2022.     Archived sources:  1.	Thai Government Public Relations Department, Facebook post (English):  https://archive.vn/2RqQd   2. Royal Thai Embassy, Beijing: "Entry requirements for entry to Thailand with effect from 11th January 2022" (English & Chinese): https://archive.vn/cZh8Y  4.	Royal Thai Embassy, Canberra: âSchemes for entering Thailandâ (English): https://archive.vn/nlmpY  5.	Tourism Authority of Thailand (English): https://archive.vn/i8WT6

Effective February 1, 2022, Thailand will resume registrations for the Test & Go program that allows fully vaccinated travellers from any country to enjoy quarantine-free entry. Additional entry requirements through this program include submitting proof of payment for two separate nights of accommodation on Day 1 and Day 5 at government-approved hotels and proof of payment for 2 RT-PCR tests. For travellers under 18 years of age, travelling with parents or guardians, the quarantine period is within the same duration as their parents or guardians.    Quarantine of 10 days is required for unvaccinated travellers.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220203172349/https://www.tatnews.org/2022/01/thailand-resumes-test-go-scheme-reopens-pattaya-and-ko-chang-sandbox-from-1-february-2022/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220204220639/https://th.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220205235707/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/thailand/entry-requirements

On 21st December 2021, the government additionally set up a relief scheme for workers in the nightlife sector, many of whom lost wages due to the continued, mandated closure of such entertainment venues, whereas other economic sectors were allowed to reopen to varying degrees. The Labour Ministry is presently disbursing a one-time payment of 5,000 baht. Freelance workers are also eligible for it, but must register with the social security scheme and also be certified by certain trade associations by 28th January 2022.     Archived source:  1.	Bangkok Post: âEntertainers register for govt aid planâ: https://archive.vn/u6KZa

On 24th January, the 4th phase of âKhon La Khreungâ, the Thai governmentâs co-payment subsidy scheme was approved. Through this scheme, the government co-pays 50% of certain living costs (food, drink and other goods and services), capped at a maximum of 150 baht/day. Phase 3 had expired on 31st December 2021, and Phase 4 will come into effect from 1st February 2022 to 30th April 2022. Coded as 1A because there are still other ongoing schemes to provide income support (such as to the nightlife workers, as mentioned in the 18th January 2022 note).     Archived sources:   1.	Bangkok Post: â4th phase of co-pay subsidy scheme approvedâ: https://archive.vn/BeffH   2. Present testing policy: lateral flow/rapid antigen tests are available to be purchased at subsidised prices. The government has also distributed some tests for free. Anyone who tests positive on a rapid test is supposed to report it and obtain a PCR test (administered by a health worker) to confirm the result.     Free PCR tests are also being offered to Thai citizens and foreign travellers who require it under the Test & Go scheme, regardless of symptoms.     Additional notes: However, there have been difficulties caused by the shortage of rapid test kits, due to the spread of Omicron increasing demand. Such shortages could impact access to PCR tests, since a positive lateral test is the gateway to getting a PCR test.     Archived source:   1. Bangkok Post: âTest kit snags worsenâ. https://archive.vn/RL1O8

Classified as limited, rather than comprehensive contact tracing (which requires both declared intention to trace for all identified cases, and evidence of capacity to do so) for the following reasons:    A.	Evidence of high daily case numbers and widespread, ongoing community transmission nationwide, that might render comprehensive contact tracing both impossible and less useful as a disease control measure as opposed to in earlier stages of the pandemic.      Thailand has been recording around 7,000+ new infections/day (as confirmed by a PCR test) for the period of 18â24 Jan 2022.     1.	Thai Department of Disease Control, official Facebook, infographic for 24 Jan 2022: â7,139 new casesâ.     Thai language version: https://archive.vn/G41zn   English language version: https://archive.vn/2nsFe     2.	https://archive.vn/4eGFF â World Health Organisation Situation Report for Thailand for 13â19 Jan 2022: Average of â7,257 new casesâ per day and âcommunity transmission of Omicron in most provinces.â     B.	Recent government guidelines state that people who discover they have Covid-19 after testing with home ATKs (antigen test kits) must report their result to the authorities, get it confirmed with a PCR test and undergo isolation. However, those with mild or no symptoms are asked to self-isolate at home in order âto ease the burden on the public health care system.â     https://archive.vn/oxD9a â Thaiger: âThailandâs updated Covid guidelines: What to do if you test positive or have symptoms.â     C.	Government strategy seems to have also shifted to making home Covid-19 tests widely available for people so they can find out if they should take a PCR test and self-isolate, and utilising vaccinations. By comparison, there does not seem to be much mention of tracing the contacts of all known cases. Nonetheless, the possibility that some contact tracing may still be going on in targeted areas is not discounted.     https://archive.vn/rvnUw â Thai Government Public Relations Department, Twitter post on making antigen kits available at low cost in response to high demand.    https://archive.vn/VEGGV and  https://archive.vn/X2JMF â Thai Government Public Relations Department, Facebook posts encouraging vaccinations. Also emphasises masking, social distancing and good hygiene, but not so much contact tracing.    https://archive.vn/BG9q9 â Bangkok Post, 19th January 2022: ââ¦[A]ll agencies tasked with quelling the outbreak [in Bangkok] have been instructed to focus their efforts on dishing out booster shots, particularly to the elderly and those with pre-existing medical conditions.â    D.	Recent mentions of contact tracing usually refer to contact tracing apps. Thai authorities have encouraged everyone to download Mor Chana and Thai Chana, Thailandâs contact tracing apps. However, this by itself does not amount to manual, comprehensive contact tracing carried out by the authorities.     Thai Government Public Relations Department, Facebook post: https://archive.vn/7UAUg   Thai PBS News: https://archive.vn/6cBgO

However, this by itself does not amount to manual, comprehensive contact tracing carried out by the authorities." No policy change. News articles detail enforcement responses by authorities over failure of tourists to wear masks in public, and complaints by parents referencing continued strict mask rules in schools for students. Thailand travel advice by foreign missions also continue to mention mask requirements and reference possible liability for fines. Additionally, on the Thai Governmentâs Public Relations Department official Facebook page; the banner states âSTOP COVIDâ¦keep wearing a mask at all times when in publicâ as of 24th January 2022.     The phrasing "advised" to "wear a mask in public" rather than "compulsory" has been used in some other government communications that were published in English, but have not found announcements actually announcing relaxation of mask rules that were instituted in 2021, so interpreted as no national policy change based on overall picture of sources.     1.	Thai Government Public Relations Department Facebook page showing banner: https://archive.vn/3kzCe   2.	Phuket News: https://web.archive.org/web/20220120183524/https://www.thephuketnews.com/patong-police-to-crack-down-on-face-masks-82803.php   3.	Thaiger: https://web.archive.org/web/20220120193907/https://thethaiger.com/news/national/parents-and-teachers-protest-against-atk-test-and-face-mask-mandates-at-schools   4.	UK Foreign Office, foreign travel advice for Thailand: https://web.archive.org/web/20220120195656/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/thailand/coronavirus  5.	Australian government travel advice for Thailand: https://web.archive.org/web/20211111013415/https://www.smartraveller.gov.au/destinations/asia/thailand

The government announced on 24th January 2022 that it will start vaccinating children aged 5-11 for the first time, from 1st February 2022 onwards. Although this group is subsumed within the larger 5-15 years old age bracket for the purposes of the dataset, the vaccines had previously been available only for children aged 12 and above.     Children aged 5-11 are not prioritised vis a vis other age brackets, as sufficient vaccines for adults are available. However, the government has said that within the 5-11 age group, it will focus on first vaccinating children who have underlying health conditions such as asthma and obesity. An initial shipment of 3 million Pfizer vaccines that will be arriving in late January is part of a larger vaccine procurement of 10 million.    Archived sources:  1. Thai Government Public Relations Department, post on official Twitter account: https://archive.vn/wDOgb   2. Bangkok Post: "Pfizer jabs for 5-11s to arrive next week.": https://archive.ph/N4knC   3. Reuters: "Thai agency approves Pfizer vaccine for use in children aged 5-11": https://archive.vn/JRURK

A State of Emergency is no longer in place in Timor-Leste. The latest one ended on 28 November 2021. Entry to national territory is no longer subject to authorisation from the Prime Minister, while entry to the country continues to be subject to medical screening. If a passenger is found infected with COVID-19, he or she will be taken to quarantine for further consultation and treatment. All passengers travelling to Timor-Leste should always present to the airport competent authorities the following: vaccination certificate and a negative COVID-19 PCR test result done within the last 72 hours before the time of departure. The test needs to be in one of these language: Indonesian, Portuguese or English. Failure to present the two documents, will be subjected to 14 days of quarantine.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220110221559/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/timor-leste/coronavirus#:~:text=Travel%2520in%2520Timor%252DLeste,be%2520subject%2520to%2520medical%2520screening.

Key Policy Responses as of July 1, 2021    FISCAL  The revised 2021 budget approved in late April includes an unprecedented fiscal response to deal with the recent COVID-19 outbreak. The COVID-19 Fund was increased to 17.7 percent of non-oil GDP. The funds will be used to purchase vaccines, protective equipment, and more material for testing and treatment. They will also finance employment support, internet connection for students, a supplement for front-line workers, and a basic consumption basket.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220117233826/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19#T

Key Policy Responses as of July 1, 2021    MONETARY AND MACRO-FINANCIAL  The authorities introduced a credit moratorium for 3 months in August 2020 which led to 23 percent of total bank loans being restructured. This scheme has been reintroduced for 2021, with an extended duration of 9 months. Moreover, the credit guarantee scheme was extended to cover micro-enterprises in addition to small and medium enterprises.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220117233826/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19#T

Key measures of the covid relief package 4.0:  Accelerating relief for individuals: In addition to administering aid in accordance with last year's standards, a subsidy is available for families with students enrolled in elementary school and below, as well as disabled students in junior and senior high school and the first three years of five-year junior colleges. Living allowances are also going out to children, young people, the elderly and the disabled in low to middle-low income households. Excluding those above a certain income, agricultural and fisheries workers, the self-employed, and workers without fixed employers also receive living allowances.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220116055359/https://english.ey.gov.tw/News3/9E5540D592A5FECD/10e57174-8e16-4710-b4ac-9882bd8db7de

Financial Relief    Three Ways to Help from Public Banks    1. Policy Lending Package: Support SMEs funding to operate business.    2. Loan Extension: Companies or individuals can apply to defer principal repayment or extend loan.    3. Credit card payment deferral: Individuals can apply to defer card payment without penalty and interest.    The measures of reducing interest rate from public banks    Residential Loan (For all loans): 0.25% lower since 2020/9/30  Consuming Loan (For all loans): 0.25% lower since 2020/9/30 (including credit card, unsecured loan, car loan)    https://web.archive.org/web/20220116055846/https://home.kpmg/xx/en/home/insights/2020/04/taiwan-government-and-institution-measures-in-response-to-covid.html

COVID-19 vaccine appointments for the first shot, second shot, or booster shot are widely available to people aged 12 or older.    Eligibility: individuals who registered on the System before 6 a.m. on December 13 and meet any of the following criteria:  1. The first dose of the BNT vaccine: people aged 12 or older (born on December 16, 2009, or earlier).  2. The second dose of the BNT vaccine: people aged 18 or older (born on December 31, 2003, or earlier) who received their first dose of BNT before November 18 (inclusive).  3. Mixing of AZ with a second dose of the BNT vaccine: people aged 18 or older (born on December 16, 2003, or earlier) who received their first dose of AZ before October 21 (inclusive).    https://web.archive.org/web/20220116062114/https://www.cdc.gov.tw/En/Bulletin/Detail/kaT7wZ1ubFZzyHlWUQsENg?typeid=158
